SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Coulter and pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Bell moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to General Business notice of motion No. 847 standing in the name of Senator Bell relating to quarrying at Exit Cave.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate on this motion is urgent because time has run out. The Government can be allowed to procrastinate no longer on this important issue. In fact, there really should be no argument from the Government on the appropriate course of action to take. It has been made obvious, and even suggested from government sources, that the time for action is now.

PARA.TAB: When Exit Cave was nominated for World Heritage listing in 1988, it was done after agreement between the Commonwealth and Tasmanian governments that quarrying could continue within the nominated World Heritage area only on the proviso that acceptable limits were set to the scale and development of the operation. Moreover, any loss that resulted from limits being subsequently placed on quarrying operations would oblige the Commonwealth to pay compensation. That is a very important point. The word `compensation' was first mentioned in what are described as the Cook-Groom heads of agreement, a document which was signed at that time and which recognised that future compensation may be a question that had to be addressed. At the time of listing, the quarry was known to be within the World Heritage area. There was agreement that compensation would be paid should limits have to be imposed on the quarry's operation.

In November 1991, a study by Kevin Kiernan proved that the quarrying operation was having a detrimental effect on the cave system. That is when the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) should have intervened and said, `Enough is enough'. The Minister should have halted operations there and then when the quarrying operation was identified as having a detrimental effect on the World Heritage area.

Instead, the Minister allowed blasting to continue in February this year to provide a sample of limestone for use by the operators, Benders, in tendering for a contract it had at that time with the zinc company, Pasminco Metals-EZ. The sample was intended to win a contract to continue to supply limestone after 30 June this year when the existing contract expires. That contract expires in less than a couple of months and that is why this matter needs to be discussed today. The time for fiddling about with this issue has long since passed.
On 24 February this year, the Tasmanian Wilderness World Heritage Area Standing Committee concluded that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . past and present quarrying operations have indisputably damaged solution cavities, sink holes and caves that are now known to be part of the Exit Cave karst subsystem.

This has been repeated in the Senate. Senator Collins, representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, has passed on to the Senate the finding of that Committee, which says:
. . . that even under the strictest environmental conditions continuation of quarrying jeopardises the area's World Heritage values.

That identifies in no uncertain terms that this operation should not continue. Exit Cave is in the World Heritage area, quarrying has a negative effect on the values of the area and the Minister has full knowledge that continuation jeopardises those values, but we have no action.

PARA.TAB: We have no tangible evidence that the Minister has taken any notice of the information which is at hand, available to her, and which, in fact, has been recognised by her. The Minister may well agree with the information that has been given. The Minister may well wish this area to be preserved and protected, but we have no tangible action. That is why we need to suspend the Standing Orders, to allow the Government to immediately act on this issue and to present to us the arguments as to why procrastination has continued. I do not see why we should have to wait for an initiative which should have been forthcoming some months ago, but which now is sadly lacking.(Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a matter of great urgency. We have the most extensive cave system in the whole of Australia—some 17 kilometres of cave—much of which remains to be explored, much of which has been identified as containing unique fauna. That cave lies in a World Heritage area that I understand was gazetted as long ago as 1989. That the Government has failed to act under its requirements to ensure that that World Heritage area is adequately protected is, indeed, a matter of urgency.

PARA.TAB: The damage to the area has been well and truly identified, by the Federal and Tasmanian departments of Environment. According to a leaked Tasmanian Department of Environment and Planning report, both that Department and the Federal Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories believe that even a new environment management plan would not protect the cave system. That report says that the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service favours relocating the quarry and the Australian Heritage Commission believes the quarry is having a significant adverse effect on the cave system.

There is no automatic protection under World Heritage for areas such as this. It does require some additional action by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly). The Minister has in the past promised to take some action, but the Minister has simply failed to carry through on that. Before more damage is done, it is urgent that action is taken at this time.

Another relevant factor is that it is not as though Tasmania is short of limestone. There is no doubt that there are many other situations in which mining can be carried out for the necessary purposes of Pasminco, the zinc refinery at Risdon near Hobart where the limestone is used. There is more than enough limestone in Tasmania in areas well away from the World Heritage area. For those reasons, it becomes absolutely vital that this damaging quarrying operation, which has been going on for quite a long time, should be stopped.

As I indicated a moment ago, the World Heritage declaration was made in 1989, but in 1991 the area around the quarry was turned into a national park. So in this particular case we have a mining operation going on which is damaging both a World Heritage area and a national park. We have an essentially industrial activity going on in a wilderness area which, as we have indicated, has been declared both World Heritage and national park. For those reasons it is absolutely urgent that the Minister make the necessary declarations so that this area is protected.

The extraction of limestone from other areas in Tasmania would, of course, employ exactly the same number of people. There is no question—as I think Senator Panizza claimed the night before last when we were debating resource security—that the Democrats want to close mining down. That is simply untrue. In this particular case we want to ensure that when this mining of limestone occurs it occurs with the same amount of employment and generates the same amount of limestone but does not go on in a World Heritage area which, as I have indicated, is in a national park.

It is for those reasons that we believe that this is a matter of urgency. The Minister, Ros Kelly, should act. She should make the necessary declaration. The mining operation should cease and should be shifted somewhere else. If compensation needs to be paid for the relocation of that mine, that compensation should also be paid. As Senator Bell has said, with the likely renewal of this mining contract on 30 June, it is important that the Minister takes the action now and does not delay any longer.
Question resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Responsibility for this legislation has been carried in this place on behalf of the Opposition by Senator Tambling. He will be speaking after I have finished. This legislation is an omnibus collection of five Bills. It is designed to bring the growing deer industry in this country in line with the major primary industries in Australia. It sets out to impose a levy on the slaughter of deer, a charge on the export of deer, a levy on the sale of deer velvet produced and sold in Australia or used in the production of other goods in Australia, and a charge on the export of deer velvet.

PARA.TAB: The deer industry is one of a number of industries that have developed in Australia over recent years. One could suggest that the industry has moved past its first excited investor stage to a secondary settling in period of expansion and consolidation. I suggest that that is the reason why at this stage the industry appears to be in such turmoil within itself over this package of Bills.

As honourable senators would be aware, the legislation passed the House of Representatives with very little fuss and with the support of the Opposition. However, by the time the legislation came to the Senate, some sections of the industry were concerned about what the Bills would mean for the industry and about the industry's capacity to meet the commitment. As a result, the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs held quite extensive hearings last Monday to provide the deer industry with an opportunity to voice its concerns.

I am advised that deer numbers in Australia have grown at the rate of, on average, about 25 per cent per annum in recent years. At present there are about 155,000 deer, on about 1,000 farms, throughout Australia made up predominantly of fallow and red deer with a small number of tropical species. I say `about' in relation to the numbers of animals and producers because quantifying that is just one of the many difficulties that this industry has. That is a problem that became increasingly evident during the Committee's hearings. To say that the industry is in a state of flux is a misconception. I would almost suggest that the industry is in chaos and on a course of self-destruction if it does not bring itself together.

Despite the industry's very short appearance at the Committee's hearings, we received some 40 submissions from growers and grower representatives. In addition, I could not count the number of calls I received on this matter, and I know other senators on the Committee also received many. They were from deer farmers both pro- and anti-levies. Obviously each one of them was concerned at what the Government and the Parliament were proposing to do for their industry. The fact that many did not know the implications of the levy—and many did not even know such legislation was intended—is a reflection as much on the industry as on its own representatives.

Having been involved with the family law inquiry for some time, I know the wisdom of not buying into a domestic dispute. I do not know where the blame lies for the fragmentation within the industry. I do know that, notwithstanding, it was not the function or the purpose of the Rural and Regional Affairs Committee to act as a mediator. The Committee Chairman tried very hard to conciliate and arbitrate between the pro- and anti-levy groups. His efforts, I am sad to say, went unrewarded. In terms of both the pro- and anti-levy people and the pro- and anti-Deer Farmers Federation of Australia, I think it can be said that people acknowledged at the end of the hearings that there was no common ground.

The Committee came to the view that, despite the criticism of some within the industry, the legislation is an appropriate path for the industry to move down. Industries must be taught to stand on their own two feet and the deer industry cannot expect to be treated any differently from any other rural group. I support both the principle and the practice of levies and that support includes the application of levies to this industry.

I would like to make some points pertinent particularly to the deer industry but also to any other industry that might be experiencing internal administrative difficulties. It is not the function nor the purpose of Parliament or any committee of Parliament to arbitrate on internal factional difficulties. It was not reasonable for this industry to expect the Rural and Regional Affairs Committee to sort out its affairs. It is up to the growers to get together and do that. It is their industry. They are the ones who should make sure that it goes the way they want it to go.

Whether or not the Deer Farmers Federation, its administrators and its executive are working in the best interests of all deer farmers is debatable. The fact that they were unable to provide accurate figures to the Committee on membership and deer population and were unable to say what percentage of deer farmers the federation represented is of concern to me, and should be of considerable concern to the deer farmers.

However, I commend the DFFA on the fact that it has now joined with the National Farmers Federation as a commodity group, which I think is a good move. To the deer farmers I say, `Your industry is in a mess and it is up to you to sort out yourselves and your affiliations. We cannot do it for you. If you continue to work in opposite directions, you will all be the losers'. The deer industry looks to be an exciting one and has great potential. It would be a pity if the breeders failed to make it work.

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of deer industry Bills has been brought about so that this industry can be in line with other agricultural industries. The Government, along with parts of the industry, has agreed to the imposition, on a shared basis between government and industry, of a research and development arrangement for this industry. The deer industry rates highly with other great Australian agricultural industries. It is expanding at a very rapid and exciting rate of approximately 25 per cent a year. There are currently about 1,000 full or part-time farmers in this industry, and 155,000 deer—a number that is expected to double within a few years.

PARA.TAB: This is also an important export industry. The deer industry's application to the Government for inclusion in the research and development arrangements will make it more commercial, more able to target what the industry is after and to embark upon the necessary research required if it is to maintain a competitiveness against the industries of other countries, in particular New Zealand.

There is already a voluntary agreement in place which the industry has instituted ahead of a statutory system and about $25,000 has been donated. When the deer industry joins the statutory arrangements in the near future it will join over 20 other agricultural industries on the same basis of a dollar for dollar up to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production. That will cost the Government an estimated $30,000 next financial year and $60,000 the following year.

It is encouraging that the industry, from its first year, is evidently prepared to provide more than is necessary for the matching grants. The grower contributions will be $100,000. It is not unique among new industries, the industries amongst these new industries or the industries that are coming into the research and development arrangements that they are prepared to go beyond the Government target.

I make the point that agricultural industries have set the example in this country of being prepared to make sacrifices for a solid research and development base, even in difficult times. This will ensure that, in spite of the problems they have, such as the very high domestic cost structure and corrupt international markets, these industries will survive.

The decision of the Deer Farmers Federation of Australia has been an important one. It has not been without criticism within the industry itself. Not everybody in the industry supports it. I believe that Senator Brownhill has made that point very clear. I suppose it would be unique actually if that were to be the case. Problems have emerged particularly with regard to full support of the industry.

The detailed steps that have taken place ahead of this legislation indicate that there is a good relationship between the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the industry and within the industry itself. There has been plenty of opportunity for the necessary discussion, communication, et cetera. In 1989, there was a deer industry workshop sponsored by the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation. On 22 March 1991, the annual meeting of the Deer Farmers Federation of Australia passed unanimously a motion to proceed with the statutory level requirement. The Tasmanian section of the industry was a member at that time and participated in that unanimous vote.

In August 1991, at a national conference held in Albury attended by over 300 deer breeders, once again there was a unanimous vote for a voluntary levy until the statutory levy commenced. On 9 October 1991, the Deer Farmers Federation of Australia formally requested a statutory levy to begin from 1 July 1992. On 21 November 1991, the Deer Farmers Council of Tasmania advised the Minister of its withdrawal from the national organisation.

Since then, there has been some conflict, a letter writing campaign and criticism. However, in recent days strong support for the proposal has emerged. For example, the Victorian Deer Farmers Association—I should mention Victoria has the largest number of deer breeders in Australia—at its meeting on 19 March passed a vote of 59 to two in favour of all levies. At an earlier time, in February 1991, at a special meeting of over 200 deer breeders there was also support for the proposal.

On 20 March, Mr John Andrews, the President of the New South Wales Association, confirmed that the New South Wales industry supported the proposal and rejected comments by a junior vice-president of that association. The Australian Fallow Deer Society Inc. at the same time indicated that it had over 50 per cent of the national herd. It gave strong support in a letter of 19 March from its President, John Holder. On the same day, the Red Deer Society of Australia—the red deer is the second largest of three commercial deer varieties—also gave strong support. It made the point that on deer produce—on all the leviable products: venison, velvet and export livestock—it will be the largest contributor. Therefore, there is also demonstrated support. I believe that there has been stronger support for the proposal than has been the case with many other industries overall. Therefore, the proposal should be supported.

I hope that the two problems I referred to earlier can be solved by negotiation and commonsense. The first of these problems concerns Tasmania, which comprises 8 per cent of the industry. Tasmania withdrew from the Association because it had been critical of the Deer Industry Development Group, which is a deer advisory body to the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation. The point has been made by the Minister for Primary Industries in Tasmania, Mr Robin Gray, that the State feels it has adequate State development arrangements for the industry and there is a request to delay the Bill to allow time for more discussions.

The industry does recognise that it has a challenge to bring the Tasmanians back into the fold. It was hoped that the Tasmanian deer farmers would be invited to the next annual general meeting of the Deer Farmers Federation of Australia. The second problem mentioned in the correspondence and in the phone calls received concerned this potential problem of double charging or double levies, namely, a levy on the animal with regard to velvet and as a live export. I believe that this is a matter of misunderstanding and I ask the Minister to clarify the position about double levying. There should not be any duplication and I anticipate there is no need for such duplication. That would then remove one of the major criticisms apparent from some of the dissidents.
I note that the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs has noted the assurances given by the Minister in the other chamber as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is not the intention of this legislation that a producer who pays a levy in relation to deer velvet for the domestic market should subsequently incur an export levy.
The Committee has also noted that clause 6(2) of the Deer Velvet Export Charge Bill 1992 specifically addressed this matter.

PARA.TAB: The Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs has also made some interesting observations which I would like to now reflect on. Firstly, the Committee found that the inquiry into and reporting on these Bills was a difficult task as it received conflicting evidence on practically every major issue raised in evidence. Secondly, having considered the evidence presented to the inquiry, the Committee recognised that the Australian deer industry is an emerging industry which will benefit from the effective research and development programs in production, processing and marketing activities. Thirdly, the Committee considered that the five Bills referred to it by the Senate will encourage this approach.

Fourthly, the Committee has concluded that the DFFA represents and has the support of a majority of the deer industry in Australia and is the appropriate avenue for consultation under the provisions of the Bills.

Finally, the Committee recommended to the Senate that the Deer Slaughter Levy Bill 1992, the Deer Velvet Levy Bill 1992, the Deer Velvet Export Charge Bill 1992, the Deer Export Charge Bill 1992 and the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Amendment Bill 1992 be agreed to. The coalition supports this legislation and commends the industry for taking that very important step to be part of the overall rural industries research and development arrangements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very important to speak on the Deer Slaughter Levy Bill 1992, the Deer Velvet Levy Bill 1992, the Deer Velvet Export Charge Bill 1992, the Deer Export Charge Bill 1992 and the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Amendment Bill 1992 at this time. This is the culmination of a process which has taken place recently over several weeks. It is a process which I take some responsibility for having initiated, that is, the process of sending this matter to the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs.

PARA.TAB: As was explained by Senator Brownhill, this legislation passed through the lower House with very little fuss and bother and very little extra attention. After that passage it reached this chamber with very little ceremony attached to it other than the statement that the levy was supported by the industry's representative body. Knowing as I did that the Tasmanian deer farmers may not necessarily be represented by that Federal body's claimed position, I took the trouble to contact a couple of known deer producers in Tasmania. My communication with them was greeted by surprise, because they had not known that this legislation would come before the chamber in such a time.

It was not just a case of a couple of lonely deer breeders in the wilds of Tasmania not keeping up with what was going on in Canberra. As I soon became aware, after communication with other deer farmers throughout Australia, it was a case of a significant number of those who are involved in this fledgling industry being unaware of what was happening in their industry. In fact, on 17 March, I was sent in writing a communication under the heading of the New South Wales Deer Farmers Association. The final part of that communication reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed levy on livestock export has not been discussed at all within the industry either at farmer level or within the Deer Farmers' Federation of Australia, of which this association is a member. Several of our members have expressed concern at its impact on their activities. We are therefore unable to support this Bill (i.e. the Deer Export Charge Bill).
We urge you to delay this until such time as the industry has had time to consider all aspects of such legislation.

As Senator Tambling, in quoting from the Committee report, observed, the committee received conflicting evidence on practically every major question considered. The first of those questions was whether the members of the industry were aware of what was going on. The fact that they were not well informed is an indictment of the body which claimed to represent the deer industry.

PARA.TAB: The result was that the deer farmers themselves were very rapidly informed—a process which perhaps should have taken place earlier because any body which asserts that it represents an industry certainly has a responsibility to effectively represent that industry. I consider that such a body must also have in place, at least, communication techniques, information gathering techniques, voting procedures and representation rules, administrative and financial records, plans for the future, processes of ratifying executive decisions, and the number of other procedures which throughout our democratic history have been established as appropriate for a body which purports to represent an industry.

At the Committee's inquiry there was considerable doubt about the accuracy of the number of deer farmers in Australia, the deer numbers and even what proportion of deer farmers were members of the Deer Farmers Federation, one way or another. Those doubts illustrate that those processes were not effectively in place.

I am pleased to believe—I have chosen those words carefully—that the process which we undertook through this Senate Standing Committee has provoked a change in the procedures and the attitudes of deer farmers to the extent that in future the processes of representation may be more cleanly and clearly defined, and that, if the Deer Farmers Federation continues to assert that it represents the industry, that association will pay greater attention to the manner in which it acquires the mandate to represent the industry. In other words, to put it simply, the Deer Farmers Association is on notice: perform, communicate or else. That is a good thing. We can be pleased to have caused that to happen.

During this whole process, while the level of representation was being discussed, I was most disappointed to pick up the impression that this level of representation was almost average, fair enough and what would be expected in rural industries. If that is fair enough, I think it is inadequate.

This is another question which should be considered perhaps at another time. It is an important question, which goes to the heart of what has been taking place under this Government over the past years. It is admirable that this Government consults with industry representative bodies. But I think it is imperative that the Government also ensure that those bodies have the mandate of those whom they claim to represent and that that mandate has been acquired legitimately and in a manner which cannot be challenged. The mandate of this body was challenged. Having been challenged, the processes have been provoked to take place. That may be very good for the industry.

The levies which were proposed were not opposed by a majority of the deer farmers of Australia. A very small number of those people who contacted me and of those people who I initiated contact with were opposed to levies per se. I do not think that they were able to justify that opposition in any way. The vast majority understood the purposes of levies and were quite happy to participate in discussions about what might be appropriate levies and how the receipt of those levies could be used.

The discussion, misinformation and misunderstandings were related to how much the levy could and should be, and to what purposes the money raised by such levies could be used. As Senator Tambling pointed out, there needed to be clarification about such matters as to whether there would be double dipping or double charging applied to people who were paying a levy for the animals themselves and then the velvet produce, which only some deer farmers were concerned about. That clarification should have been achieved before this matter reached this chamber, not after. As I say, I think we have provoked the processes to take place so that it is possible in the future to clarify those things before rather than during.

There are a number of other matters that I could go into now. If anybody is particularly interested in them, they are well documented in the Hansard of the Committee's inquiry. That Hansard provides interesting reading for anybody who is interested in not just the deer industry, and not where the deer industry is going, which is a fascinating enough story in itself; the Hansard provides an illustration of the sorts of conflicts which arise when inefficient communication processes are in place in a formative industry.

It is the responsibility of the industry, as previously mentioned, to establish more suitable communication processes, and to ensure that the communication processes result in a representative body which represents the industry. It is also the responsibility of the industry to be able to communicate effectively with the Government if it wants the assistance of government. The assistance of government is in the regulation of these sorts of things, such as levies.

The other role of government is to ensure that what might at first appear to be the sensible thing and a reasonable path to follow does not act against the interests of the industry itself. I am reminded of the contrary point of view which is put against applying too high a levy in the initial sense. It is pretty obvious that our initial and most dangerous competitor in this industry is New Zealand, which has access to our markets under CER. Any levy which is applied in Australia should be applied with the knowledge of what levies apply in New Zealand. If we tax or levy our producers at a rate which is in excess of those in New Zealand, we are immediately placing them at a considerable disadvantage. All producers must be aware of that disadvantage.

The Tasmanian industry was mentioned and it is a fact that its producers have unanimously, as a cohesive body, directed themselves towards meeting the New Zealand producers head on in terms of handling techniques, breeding techniques, production and marketing. They have successfully met that challenge. To be undermined by an industry wide levy placed at an inappropriate level is something which the Tasmanian producers, who have been at the forefront of this industry, do not deserve and it is most unfair.

In meeting and overcoming the challenge of the New Zealand producers, our Tasmanian producers have shown a level of cooperation with each other and a level of initiative and enterprise which should be admired and protected—not protected by levies and tariffs willy-nilly but by proper forethought before we just accept the recommendations of a body which may or may not represent the industry. We have been alerted through this process to those problems. I hope that the DFFA takes seriously my suggestion that that body is on notice to perform, communicate, consult and inform—or else.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us the Deer Slaughter Levy Bill 1992, the Deer Velvet Levy Bill 1992, the Deer Velvet Export Charge Bill 1992, the Deer Export Charge Bill 1992 and the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Amendment Bill 1992. Although my comments will be consistent with those of the previous speakers, there are just a couple of points I will highlight.

PARA.TAB: I acknowledge the difficulty that the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs had in coming to a position on this issue. I am pleased that Senator Burns, who is Chairman of the Committee, is in the chamber because there has been a misunderstanding. Apparently, I am supposed to have criticised him for not being impartial and fair in his handling of that Committee. I put it on the public record that that is not true; I did not criticise him. As Chairman of the Rural and Regional Affairs Committee, he has been very fair to all members of that Committee, totally impartial and very constructive and helpful.

I make the point that I went very close to putting in a minority report as a result of this hearing. The industry is so divided and there was so much divisiveness between the various parties in the evidence that was put before us. Like other speakers, I believe that we have to put the deer industry itself—not only the DFFA but also some of the other participants in the deer industry—on notice that it should not take for granted the fact that the Committee came down in favour of agreeing to the implementation of this levy and assume that it is there for ever and a day.

I think it is very important, particularly as we go through the first 12 months, that the deer industry really gets its act into gear as an industry and that it comes back to this Parliament when it wants the period of the levy extended with a much more united and researched position and a much clearer direction as to what the funds are for. I will come to that particular aspect of the matter in a moment or two. The evidence was so conflicting that it really made a decision almost impossible. It was not just disagreement on a few minor points; it was almost total disagreement on every point.

In the past I have supported research and development for other industries; other industries need to consider their position on research and development levies. Senator Bell gave a clear outline of this matter in regard to representation and communication within the various industries.

I do not accept some parts of the evidence. For example, I do not accept that membership of the DFFA is the norm. It may be the norm in some industries, but I know for a fact that it is not the norm in a number of industry organisations, particularly in Western Australia. It is important that national executive officers or presidents of organisations get some of the fundamental facts correct.

Let me give some idea of the conflict as set out in the Committee's report. To the best of my knowledge, the levy legislation has been agreed to almost unanimously. The report refers to the associations of Western Australia, South Australia, Victoria, Queensland and New South Wales, and I shall refer to Tasmania in a moment. The report also refers to the Red Deer Society and the Fallow Deer Society. On page 4 the report refers to evidence given to the Committee that the industry had not been consulted adequately about the Bills, and that the Deer Farmers Federation of Australia, proponent of the Bills, does not represent the industry.

I found it incredible, as I am sure did other members of the Committee, that in terms of a levy of this nature and the amount involved, when the report was released and the heat was on, the phone did not stop ringing for three or four days with people seeking to put their views. I believe that the time to put information and evidence to a committee is prior to its hearings rather than afterwards. We did receive some useful information after the hearing. But one must say to the DFFA, the Tasmanian organisation or any other part of the industry involved in the processing or manufacturing of deer products that they need to make sure that they get the process right and put in submissions and information prior to the hearings. I put on notice that I will not be quite so tolerant to latecomers in the future.

One of the things that tipped me in favour, though very marginally, towards supporting the Bills was the RIRDC report, which was given to us by the managing director, Mr Keith Hyde. I draw the Senate's attention to appendix 5 of the report. What concerned me greatly, and I questioned in depth the various proponents, was the apparent incestuous relationship that appeared to exist with respect to the presentation of the table spelling out how the funds were to be spent. In particular, I refer to the DFFA as the proponent of the levy on behalf of the industry. We found from the was presented to us that the DFFA could well be a major beneficiary of the levy.

For example, if we look down the table, we see one particular item for research and development—namely, velvet training language and training. If we go across the table, we see under the column for 1991-92 the figure of $46,850. For 1992-93, there is a figure of $10,000. The recipient of it is the DFFA and the Velvet Committee. Further down the table is a similar situation, with different figures for communications for RIRDC and the DFFA. The same format is used for program management.

I was most concerned about that table. It also lists items such as information systems for livestock and market, both domestic and international. For 1991-92 there is an amount of $10,000 and for 1992-93 it is $15,000. The recipient of this is the DFFA and Bob Coombs. As I am sure most honourable senators would know, Bob Coombs is the equivalent of the Executive Director to the DFFA. In terms of the presentation of this table, I was most concerned about the apparent potential for an incestuous relationship between the raising of these funds and the purpose for which they are nominated.

It was only after the hearing that I received a phone call from a Mr Peter McInnes, the Chairman of what is known as the DIDG Committee. This was when the industry was very disorganised. When he spoke to me, I raised the issue of whether the funds were truly going to research and development or whether they could well be siphoned off for the administrative purposes of running the DFFA and possibly even making a contribution to the salaries of some of the people employed there. Mr McInnes sent a paper to the Secretary of the Committee, Mr Neil Bessell, the last paragraph of which I will now read. It will now be on the public record for people to observe. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Owing to a lack of information on deer industry statistics and activities, funds have also been recommended and approved for improved information and communications systems for the industry. A contract has been organised for Rural Action to undertaken this R&D and Information/ Technology Transfer. Rural Action is owned by Bob and Barbara Coombs and as Mr Coombs is part-time Executive Director of the DFFA he is ideally qualified and experienced to supervise this project in the capacity of a private contractor. Once again accounting and auditing requirements will be monitored by RIRDC.

Once again, I put on public notice to RIRDC that we will need to see those accounting and auditing processes in this Parliament. In terms of setting a statutory levy, it is absolutely essential that we are assured that the funds raised will be used for the purpose for which they are meant.

PARA.TAB: My final comment on this matter is that, in the broader context, I believe the time has come for a very close analysis of the raising of research and development or other funds through compulsory levies.

TALK.START.PARA: —We need a referendum.

—We need to look very closely at whether this compulsion that has been applied through most agricultural research and development levies is in fact the wish of the growers and is giving a return on that investment. In the final analysis, the individual contributors to these levies have little say on where they are spent and the type of functions or processes that they are used for. At the very least, as my colleague Senator Panizza has suggested, from time to time there should be a referendum as to whether the industry wishes to continue with these types of levies. That in itself would increase enormously the communications back to the individual contributors. It would mean that the recipients of the funds and those who promote the raising of them would have to inform the contributors of their results in a practical, pragmatic and constructive way.

PARA.TAB: If these Bills have done nothing other than crystallise our minds on the compulsory raising of funds, they have been a good thing. I close my remarks by saying once again that the deer industry should not take it for granted that this legislation—now that we have agreed to it at the committee level, and it will pass through this Parliament—is there for ever and a day. The industry should take on notice that it is important that it gets its auditing and accounting processes in place. Those processes justify to the industry and this Parliament that the funds are being spent for the purposes for which they were intended.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, I wish to say a few words about the Deer Slaughter Levy Bill 1992, the Deer Velvet Levy Bill 1992, the Deer Velvet Export Charge Bill 1992, the Deer Export Charge Bill 1992 and the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Amendment Bill 1992. The referral of these Bills to the Committee generated considerable interest; indeed, over 50 submissions were lodged with the Committee and several members of the Committee received numerous telephone calls about specific aspects of the Bills.

PARA.TAB: The Committee held a public hearing on Monday, 27 April 1992, inviting witnesses from the industry, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the Rural Industries Research and Development Corporation to give evidence on proposals to collect levies and charges for research and development in the deer industry. There was a voluntary levy in the previous 12 months which, in accordance with evidence given, will raise about $60,000 as compared with $100,000 under a statutory levy. I suggest that is a fairly good effort by the deer farmers; it shows a fairly large degree of support for the industry from deer farmers as distinct from members of the Deer Farmers Federation of Australia.

At the Committee hearing I raised the question of the use of that money in a positive and useful way. I am always concerned when organisations begin a new process or activity that a large amount of the money which is raised goes to executive salaries and no real work is done. I was informed by RIRDC that an amount of about $15,000 would go in administration costs from a total amount of $300,000. I think that is a reasonable amount.

The Committee's task was not easy as it received conflicting evidence on practically every major issue raised in the evidence. I am sure I speak on behalf of the other members of the Committee when I say that we were all concerned about the divisiveness and the disunity within this emerging industry. At the public hearing I proposed—and the Committee agreed—that all the witnesses be brought together at the table so the Committee could explore whether there was any common ground on which it could base a recommendation on these Bills to the Senate. Unfortunately, this process of conciliation was not taken up by all participants. My offer to assist by chairing a meeting of the parties continues to stand.

Where there is any concern or question in relation to the way in which the money is spent and its accountability, it would seem to me that that is an issue that has to be kept quite separate from the issue as to whether the levy should be raised. The people who have the money and who spend it should be subject to quite stringent auditing and the Committee has considered that aspect of the matter as well.

The Committee has looked carefully at the Bills and at the evidence presented to it and its report notes concerns expressed by witnesses about aspects of the industry. These concerns were sufficient for the Committee to commit itself to a review of the legislation in about 15 months time. If necessary, the Committee will seek a formal reference from the Senate at that time.

That makes it very clear that while we have some reservations about the best way in which we think it should operate, we are prepared to give that opportunity. But we want the right—and we certainly would expect the support of the Senate in this matter—to examine what happens in those 15 months. Nevertheless, for the reasons contained in its report, the Committee recommends that the Bills be agreed to without amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I inform the Senate that I was not on the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, nor am I a deer farmer. The closest I have been to a deer is on the occasions that I have seen one over a fence when I was driving down main roads, or when I have seen the logo on John Deere tractors.
—Or eating venison!

—No, I have not eaten venison, but obviously that pleasure awaits me. The mechanics of the Deer Slaughter Levy Bill 1992 and the four related Bills have already been ably explained by Senator Tambling, so I will not go into the details as time is getting on.

PARA.TAB: I rise to put the view of Western Australian deer farmers, as they have asked me to do. There is obviously a lot of conflict, as Senator Burns has pointed out. To date there has been voluntary funding for R&D, which Senator Burns said amounted to $60,000, and this proposed mandatory research and development will raise about $100,000. I question whether it is worth the powder and shot anyway as obviously most of the difference of $40,000 will be used up in the collection process. But the Government has decided through this legislation to put R&D on a mandatory basis and to move away from voluntary contributions.

I move to the position in Western Australia as it has been put to me. The call for a compulsory levy came from a very small part of the industry in terms of numbers of stock run. I believe that the call has come too early, as the industry is still in its infancy and is still very small. There are only about 145,000 deer in Australia, and I believe we should have stayed with the voluntary arrangements for now. The voluntary arrangements and any other arrangements that have been in force should have been the way to go until the industry got a lot bigger.

The Deer Farmers Federation of Australia, the DFFA, claims that it represents the majority of deer farmers. Well, operators in Western Australia dispute that assertion; it is similar to what is said in a lot of other agricultural commodity industries. They claim to represent the industry and they come here and ask for mandatory levies to fund research and development without going out to their members or the growers to ask them whether they want this to happen. Senator Crane mentioned this, and the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) in the other place often refers to this matter. If one wants a compulsory levy one should have a referendum among the growers, and not just consult an association that may have an axe to grind on the matter.

I return to the position in Western Australia. The traditional farmers there claim that the call for a compulsory levy came from hobby farmers, and I believe that. I have seen a few deer being run on small hobby farms near Perth because it is the `in' thing to do. In time it may well grow into a big industry. The people who have spoken to me claim that only eight deer farmers in WA use their farms as a main source of income—in other words, 75 per cent of income. Of those eight farmers, only four agree with this proposal. Half the people in Western Australia who receive their main income from deer farming are against it. Therefore, it can hardly be said that the DFFA is representative of people's views. This really means that the hobby farmers, with their own peculiar sort of views—and I emphasise that they are not traditional farmers—are imposing their will not only on the rest of Western Australia but on the rest of Australia.

What worries me is that there is no plan of action as to the way in which this money is going to be spent. When a compulsory levy is sought one presumes that a detailed plan will be presented including preliminary accounts of what is to be done with it. Senator Crane touched on this—most of the money could be going to the DFFA itself. At this stage it is probably only an accusation, but on behalf of the Western Australian deer farmers I would certainly like to know a bit more about that.

As I said before, there are only about 145,000 deer in Australia at the moment. Of that number, one-third is breeding stock, one-third is for velvet and approximately one-third is for slaughter. This is a slaughter levy Bill, but when one works out how many grams of meat would be available throughout Australia, the amount is very small. If we are looking for exports through the R&D program, where are we going to get them from? The 145,000 head that we have is hardly enough for use in Australia without looking for exports. Perhaps the deer industry will be a big industry in times to come but it is really in its infancy now.

As I said before, this compulsory levy is way ahead of its time. Most of the deer farming in Australia at present is hobby farming, and I think it should remain that way. High prices have been paid for stock in Australia, mainly in the stud market. As with racehorses, cattle and merino sheep, the biggest money is made from stud for a while then, when the numbers build up, prices go down.

The points I have made express the fears of the Western Australian deer farmers. I know that we are supporting the legislation but I would certainly like a lot of the questions asked by Senator Burns, Senator Crane and myself answered before I could really have my heart in the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a brief contribution to this debate on the Deer Slaughter Levy Bill 1992, the Deer Velvet Levy Bill 1992, the Deer Velvet Export Charge Bill 1992, the Deer Export Charge Bill 1992 and the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Amendment Bill 1992, because we have been asked to curtail our remarks. Since the end of February I have had considerable discussions with various Tasmanian growers and association officers.

PARA.TAB: The industry in Tasmania is only small but it has been very well organised and has been a very happy, tight little group. The membership is between 70 and 80—it was 72 as at 30 June 1991 when there were about 13,278 head of deer behind wire. It is well organised, soundly based and is already running a very sound operation. It has run its own levy system for some time and serviced its members very well. It has concentrated on developing the industry around filling particular niches. That is where it has had its disagreements with the Australian body and that is why it left and is no longer affiliated. The Australian body was going in a completely different direction—a direction that did not suit the Tasmania industry in any way.

Having had these discussions, I have tried to come to conclusions about what is to be done. Clearly, there are advantages in having a national industry but not just for the sake of having a national industry. I started to look at the membership of these groups and I found that there are three categories of deer farmers, the same as there are in most other livestock operations. There is the investor group—the people who have the money and decide that deer is the thing to be in, and then go out and make a big investment. There are the hobbyists, the people who have a handful of deer—probably 10, 20, 30 or something—and they, too, believe that they will have a nice little backyard hobby. Thirdly, there are the genuine farmers who are in it as an ordinary business, as another livestock operation.

It is the first two groups that have created the pressure here, as it usually is in these types of organisations. They believe, usually, that it requires government to come in to resolve the problems. I have never found that to be the case at all. I have found that the problems usually come with the government. One of the three great lies is: `I am from the Government and I am here to help you'. It is very much the case, I believe, with these types of organisations. The Government can help only if the industry is in good order and condition.

In this case, not one person involved in the deer industry in Australia could say that the industry overall is in good order and condition. It is clearly not. There is, I think, a relatively low proportion of growers involved in the association. One of the States pulling out altogether demonstrates that the organisation is not as sound as it should be. I plead with the Minister not to race in to get this legislation enacted until we have these problems ironed out. That may be 12 or 18 months or two years away. I do not mind, but I would not want to see this put into force straight away.

A levy of $100,000 for 155,000 head of deer represents about 10 per cent of the value of the venison meat that is sold. It is necessary with a small, high-priced, high-value article to make sure that the niche marketing works properly. This is where the Tasmanian industry has done so well. It has worked on a niche market idea. The Australian body believes that the best thing it can do with the funds that are to be raised is to spend them on generic advertising—just advertising venison as the thing to eat.

We should remember that the New Zealand industry is just across the Tasman. If we start advertising deer generically with no reference to the real features of it, we are going to do wonderful things for the New Zealand industry and possibly horrible things to the Australian one. That is the sort of thing that has to be resolved long before we get this deer farming operation in action. We do not want to race into something that will react against our producers. Most of all, we have to see that it works for them.

For this to work, the industry will require the best people in Australia, not just the wealthiest or the biggest but the ones who can make the greatest contribution. I have had people ring me from various places giving me their credentials as to why they are on the Deer Farmers Federation and so on. That does not necessarily mean they are the best. The results that the Deer Farmers Federation has put together have clearly indicated to me that someone on that board obviously does not have the best interests of the deer industry in mind.

All we can ask the Minister is that he hastens slowly; that he ensures that, before this legislation is enacted, all the little wrinkles and bubbles between the various members and States are ironed out properly and thoroughly. Also, he should ensure that the arrangements are appropriately in hand before the legislation is put into effect.

The research and development aspects are very important but there are a lot of areas in which this money could be spent other than this generic advertising which we are talking about. There is so much to be learnt yet about the handling of deer, about the control and fencing of them, the breeding, the diseases and so on. All those things need to be well and truly put into this schedule of what is to be done. It is not just a matter of going out and promoting the fact that people should eat more deer.
I would just like to read two paragraphs of a letter I received from the Tasmanian Minister for Primary Industries, Mr Robin Gray, on the matter. The letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The deer industry in Tasmania is in the critical stage of development and will not receive any benefit from the early years of levy payments unless funds are made available to the State to develop its own marketing strategy: a strategy which is being pursued with vigour and is supported by the Tasmanian Development Authority and the Department of Primary Industry, Fisheries and Energy.

The Deer Farmers' Council of Tasmania does not support the direction the National body is taking because the bulk of the funds will be used to develop a generic National marketing scheme with emphasis on red deer. There was grave concern that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet is still refusing to allow the Cabinet minutes of 1977 to be released onto the public record.

There is in existence a letter from the DPP saying that, in his view, the documents could in fact be construed as already being on the public record. I would say that, as a result of that letter having been written, the DPP was heavied by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet because we received a subsequent letter saying, `We might have to get a legal opinion'. Quite clearly, this is not in the public interest and it is totally unacceptable.

These Cabinet minutes were finally produced in a court hearing—the original Midford hearing—when the magistrate threw the action out, castigated the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce and indeed was critical of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet which, despite the fact that the court wanted to see those documents, was still trying to resist their being produced. TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, there is a longstanding practice, certainly observed by Westminster-style governments with a parliamentary executive and Cabinet system, that Cabinet minutes are not made available to the public. There was a decision by this Parliament under the Freedom of Information Act that such documents are not released for a period of 30 years, as I recall. I was on a Senate committee which looked at the whole question.

PARA.TAB: So Parliament has already endorsed the general principle that the minutes of Cabinet meetings ought not to be put on the public record for the very obvious reason that, if one wants to have the highest level of frankness between Ministers leading to the development of policy, those documents ought not to be released in a way which might jeopardise future frank discussions between Ministers. That is the general policy.

As I understand it, the documents made available to the court allowed—from Senator Bishop's point of view and probably from an objective point of view—a just outcome which otherwise might not have occurred. But they were made available on a confidential basis.

There is also the question of the availability of these documents to an appropriate committee. As I understand it, they were made available to the Public Accounts Committee, once again on the basis of confidentiality under the section of this Parliament's statute which regulates the way in which such material can be made available to that sort of committee. As I understand it, it was on the basis of that section applying that Dr Hewson agreed, as the current leader of the political party in office at the time of the Cabinet meeting under discussion, to give his concurrence to the material being made available.

The situation is that the Cabinet office has acted, as far as is possible, in line with ordinary principles relating to the release of Cabinet documents. Where they have been supplied, they have been supplied to the court or to the parliamentary committee on a confidential basis. As I understand it, the release to the Committee was made with the concurrence of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) on that basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make a point about the officiousness of the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet. PARA.TAB: If the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate) read the letter that came from a rather junior officer in the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet written to the Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee, he might be just as angry as I am. The contention and the difficulty we have is that these documents, which were pivotal to somebody's freedom, were able to be brought before the court against the bureaucratic wishes of the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet. Once that pivotal evidence was brought before the court, the matter was thrown out—after wasting at least $1m of taxpayers' money in prosecuting this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the sequence was something like this: during the committal proceedings the Commonwealth appeared, through counsel, on 5 June 1989; some discussion took place between the various counsel and the magistrate as to how to deal with a number of Cabinet documents; and the magistrate made an order on that day in relation to the Cabinet documents then sought to be dealt with in the following terms:

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot impute that.

I attach a copy of the relevant part of the transcript of the committal proceedings. I doubt whether the order made on 5 June 1989 can have had any effect once the documents were admitted as exhibits. However, that is an issue on which the Committee may wish to obtain its own legal advice.

I wish to make the point that, contrary to what Senator Tate told us a few moments ago, the DPP took the view that, at the time the documents were tendered to become exhibits, the admitting of those documents eroded the condition attached to the earlier order and, accordingly, they became part of the public record.

PARA.TAB: That is not what Senator Tate told us. He said that there simply was nobody there—that they were not quick enough, that they were incompetent, or something of that nature. That is simply not the case. The Director of Public Prosecutions has told us in this letter that he deliberately formed the view that that condition had been eroded and did not apply.

He then alludes to what is quite clearly a heavying exercise by the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet—that in fact the condition did continue to apply; that despite the fact that something is on the public record, it is somehow confidential and cannot be mentioned. Everybody needs to be properly informed as to the way the whole matter was conducted. I would ask the Minister to ensure that a serious reconsideration be given to this matter. Bureaucratic attitudes should not be considered and public interest should be the dominant force.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Tasmania—Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs) (12.27 p.m.)—Senator Bishop has completely misrepresented what I have told the chamber. The honourable senator read a second letter—which I have not read—from the Director of Public Prosecutions and I agree with everything that he has said. What I have said is consistent with what he has said—namely, that the order made by the magistrate does not apply to these three extra documents and that, therefore, during the course of proceedings they became public documents. I agreed with all of that. I have said that. —It is not a relaxing matter.

—No, but give me a chance. PARA.TAB: Secondly, there is a longstanding practice observed by the leaders of all political parties in relation to Cabinet documents that they give their concurrence, subject to strict conditions, to the release of those public documents when asked to do so. As I understand it, in this case the general condition agreed to by Dr Hewson, for example, in allowing the release of the documents to the parliamentary Committee was the basis of confidentiality enshrined in the statutes relating to that Committee's operations. Thirdly, we would need to take into account the general policy evident behind the formulation by this Parliament of the Freedom of Information Act. We must be careful to keep in mind that general policy in relation to any particular matter.

In other words, the honourable senator asked for this to be looked at in the light of public policy considerations. To be fair to officers, I think it has to be looked at in a very wide context. It certainly ought to be looked at in the context of this Parliament's own statutes which deal with the release of such information. I undertake to give serious consideration to those policy issues in the light of this specific instance and not wait for some general reconsideration of FOI principles. But clearly it would have to be taken in the context of this Parliament's express wish in relation to FOI principles.

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks relating to the freedom of information question are simply a reminder to the Government. I would be grateful if the Minister could convey the message to his colleague, the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy). Perhaps this will make him hurry up and re-make the regulations to effect the recommendation in the report regarding the highly unsatisfactory situation where certificates which preclude the release of information in perpetuity can be issued.

PARA.TAB: I am anxious to see the committee's recommendation of a two-year limit followed. This is the desirable limit—certainly not five years as the original regulation provided. I also want to see some mechanism whereby someone who is a third party can also have the right to have a decision reviewed. That is quite aside from the question that I am addressing with regard to the specific documents that were tendered to the court and which became part of the public record.

I think the matter that the Minister raised as a side issue of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) giving his concurrence, almost comes in the category of a red herring. I would be almost prepared to lay money on it that nobody told the Leader of the Opposition at the time that these documents had in fact been made part of the public record and tendered in court. I would be most interested to see any evidence to the contrary.

On the second point, I think it is the most extraordinary argument that I have heard for a long time that documents that have become part of the public record can suddenly be reconverted into being private, confidential and protected by statutes from which they have already been exempted. I would have thought that the decision made by the court was the precedent that ought to be followed. I do, however, accept the Minister's undertaking to examine the need for the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet to reconsider its bureaucratic action in continuing to argue that the documents made available to us have been made available on a confidential-only basis. Presumably, the Minister is arguing that if the documents can be obtained from somewhere else, there is no problem. But we want it to be done correctly.

I accept the Minister's undertaking that he will look at the question of whether confidential documents can be released and provided to us so that in the public interest, and as a matter of public policy, the Senate can be properly informed when this report comes into this chamber. People who are very widely interested in this case will be able to make a proper judgment based on the facts and will not be subject to the veil of secrecy which has surrounded so much of this matter for so long.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. What will be the trade-off for the superannuation guarantee levy? Will it be a reduction of 3 per cent to 4 per cent of average weekly earnings, estimated by the Treasury as the equivalent impact of the levy, or will it be the loss of another 100,000 jobs over the next five years, again as indicated by Treasury?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —This issue has been discussed in a variety of places and everybody, particularly Opposition members, will have a go at trying to provide an answer that suits them. The Treasury submission on this matter—considered, as I understand it, at some length—does not expect job losses from the introduction of the superannuation guarantee levy. In fact, the submission states:

ANSWER.PARA: It is expected that the cost of the SGL will be largely, if not totally, offset by lower growth on other forms of remuneration, especially wages.
The Government, as distinct from the Opposition, has a capacity to do that. We have shown that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, cut living standards.

—Senator Kemp is always vocal on these matters, but is a bad historian, I am afraid. He should pause for a moment to remember what happened in wages in the last years of the last Liberal Government. They went up by 14 per cent, 16 per cent and 16 per cent in three years.
—You have shown you don't know what to do.

PARA.TAB: Senator Robert Ray—You were in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberals were in government and were supposed to be running the country, but that is what happened to wages.
—What about answering the question.

—Senator Kemp interjected and I am entitled to deal with his interjection. The Government and the ACTU have given a commitment that increases in the levy will be taken into account in future wage negotiations. I reiterate that we have the capacity to do that; the Opposition does not. The Opposition would have its scorched earth industrial relations policy, which would produce the same sort of blow-out as occurred in the last years of the last Liberal Government.

PARA.TAB: Aside from this assurance from the ACTU, we have also stated that the timetable for increases in the superannuation guarantee levy support would be reconsidered if wages growth were to be inconsistent with sustaining lower inflation. Sustaining lower inflation is something we are entitled to speak about—we have done it. When the Opposition was in government, it was not able to do that, and it will not be able to do it again. The Opposition's Fightback package is a recipe for increased inflation at a time when we are trying to introduce some discipline and rigour into the wages system in this country.

The numbers reported in the press about this matter are a worst case scenario, which assumes that SGL increases are not in lieu of wage increases. That is that worst case scenario which Senator Short has picked up and which is implicit in his question.

Since March 1983, real unit labour costs have fallen by 9.5 per cent. The forecast for average earnings growth in 1991-92 is the lowest for over two decades. These things are relevant to the management of the economy and of this country. They are things which the Opposition ought to address.

TALK.START.PARA: —Look at the unemployment level.
—Senator Kemp is back on the unemployment figure again, a matter which causes him great delight. The higher unemployment rises, the noisier Senator Kemp gets.

—I conclude by saying that the superannuation guarantee levy, which is a matter of Government policy, has to be managed carefully. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to Senator Button in his capacity as Minister representing the Treasurer. Can the Minister outline the reasons behind the Government's and Reserve Bank's decision to lower interest rates today? What is the Government's expectation about the impact of the reduction in interest rates?

—Of course, the decision of the Reserve Bank and the announcement by the Treasurer of a lowering of cash rates by one percentage point are important. That will bring cash rates down to 6 1/2 per cent. Short term interest rates have now reached their lowest level since the mid-1970s. Long term interest rates have fallen to levels not seen since the late 1970s.

PARA.TAB: The lowering of interest rates reflects importantly the progress that has been made in reducing inflation and inflationary expectations in Australia. Progress on inflation means that lower interest rates are sustainable. CPI inflation is now down to 1.7 per cent, which is below the latest average annual inflation rate of 2.5 per cent for our OECD trading partners. The underlying rate, excluding volatile and seasonal factors, is now down to about 3 per cent. This is the lowest underlying rate since the index was first calculated in 1971.

The reason interest rates are back down to the levels of the 1970s is that inflation is now back to well below the levels of the 1970s, and this Government intends to keep them there. When I talk about the levels of the 1970s, I am excluding the last period of Liberal Party government when the inflation rates were in double digit figures, unemployment rates were in double digit figures and interest rates were further above that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Whitlam years?
—I am talking about the period of the mid-1970s. Senator Short talks about the Whitlam years. The mid-1970s were two years after the Whitlam years, at best.
—What about the Whitlam years? Don't forget them.

—I do not forget them. I am just reminding those opposite about the good performance that was attained in the mid-1970s, the terrible performance that obtained when the Liberals went out of office and the very great performance which this Government has recorded in respect of inflation and interest rates.

PARA.TAB: The Government's CPI forecast for 1992-93 is now 2 1/2 per cent compared with a figure of 3 1/2 per cent published in the Prime Minister's One Nation statement in February. I think the only threat to that is the introduction of an industrial relations policy of the kind which Opposition senators seem to be advocating now—the so-called big bang industry policy which, I assure the Opposition, will produce big bang wages policies and be a threat to inflation and, of course, to interest rates.

The measures announced in the One Nation statement, together with the cumulative effects of the successive easing of monetary policy, are helping to drive the recovery and to secure it. The Government expects today's reduction in cash rates to be passed on promptly by the banking system. I must say as Industry Minister that I am particularly concerned that these reductions be passed on to small and medium sized business borrowers, many of whom are still paying relatively high overdraft rates. Banks and their business customers should seek to use cheaper financing through bills in order to take full advantage of the lower interest rate structure.

The Government also expects the reduced cash rates to be reflected in reduced rates for existing home mortgages as well as for people who obtain new mortgages. Hopefully, they will be reflected in credit card interest rates, which have not fallen in line with the reductions in other interest rates since 1990. Lower rates for housing and credit cards do not just benefit the consumers. The resultant increase in disposable income has a generally good effect in the economy in increasing demand and contributing to the recovery of the business sector.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the report that a jar of baby food laced with cyanide has been sent to a Perth police station? A letter has also been sent to the police station linking the poisoned baby food with the acquittal of four Los Angeles police officers last week. Could the Minister inform the Senate of action that is being taken to protect consumers from reported tampering with baby food products? Is the danger confined to reusable containers?

—It is true that a couple of days ago Western Australian police alerted consumers to a threat involving the contamination of a container of baby food. A product sample sent to Perth police described as rosehip gel manufactured by Heinz and contained in glass jars was found to contain potentially fatal quantities of cyanide. Heinz has withdrawn those product lines in glass jars in Western Australia; no other States have been nominated at this time.

PARA.TAB: The police received a letter with the jar of baby food warning that five babies will die as retribution for the acquittal of Los Angeles police involved in the Rodney King case—unbelievable! At this time, there is no evidence that items removed from supermarket shelves in the course of this recall have been contaminated. Consumers in Western Australia have been advised not to use any baby food products in glass jars purchased since Thursday, 30 April, and either to return the products to the point of sale or to dispose of them.

The Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs, of course, is liaising with the National Food Authority and Heinz officials to determine that appropriate action is being taken by the company to protect consumers from the potentially serious hazards—and, of course, as I say, Heinz has cooperated in the withdrawal of those product lines from Western Australia. The National Food Authority, having responsibility for food safety, is coordinating that particular recall.

Most baby food products sold in glass jars, including the Heinz range, have a vacuum sealed lid which pops when opened. Should the glass jar not pop or should the container not have a properly depressed lid, the consumer should notify the store management immediately and under no circumstances use the product.
