PARA.TAB: I think Mr Blount explained to the Caucus—I was not there—that AOTC is doing some re-engineering of all of the divisions to see what it comes up with at the end of the day for staff numbers. That process will take quite some time. It will involve the union movement in every step so that there is full consultation with the work force as to what its future is likely to be. I cannot give Senator Powell a figure on what the job loss might be. I have not been given one in any of the discussions that I have had with AOTC.

As far as the rest of the question is concerned, it should be noted that the corporate plan will be discussed by the AOTC board during the next week. It will be made public very shortly. It would probably be more appropriate that I comment when it is made public.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the industry plan?

—The industry plan was released a couple of weeks ago. As a result of that plan and what Optus is doing, there is no question that during the next decade the telecommunications industry in Australia will grow—I think spectacularly.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister have any comfort for AOTC workers who in this restructuring, particularly in rural areas, may have to wait some years before they are picked up by the competitor? The Minister's former portfolio, the Department of Social Security, will have spent all of its ready cash by then. Does this mean that the Government may as well have privatised in the first place, which the Opposition will do after the next election in any case?

—The Opposition has to win the election to do that, and I do not think it will, so that is not a problem. I think Mr Blount explained to the Caucus that AOTC will be most sensitive in rural areas. In many country towns, there are small depots with one to 10 people who are particularly important to those rural communities. That is where AOTC will be most sensitive. The first priority will be to try to redeploy within the organisation. Even if people are not doing the same task, they will still have a job within the organisation. After that, there will undoubtedly be some redundancies. We will try hardest in rural communities to maintain staff numbers because the viability of many towns is dependent upon, in many cases, AOTC's presence.

—Does the Minister for Industrial Relations agree that today's article by the economics editor of the Australian, Alan Wood, suggests that all employees would be capable of negotiating non-exploitative employment contracts with their employers without the assistance of a trade union or the Australian Industrial Relations Commission? Is the Government contemplating changing its industrial relations policies to reflect Mr Wood's view or will it maintain its current policies which prevent workers in vulnerable positions in the labour market from being exploited?
—Yesterday's question.
—Let's have yesterday's answer.

—In answer to the manifest interjections in this chamber, the article that Senator Devereux referred to was in yesterday's paper, but the article exists. The question is therefore a substantial one and worth a reply. It is said that if you want to have an operation, visit a surgeon; if you want to be treated, visit a physician; and if you prefer a natural cure, visit a herbalist. Dr Wood is an economist and the economics editor of the Australian. He writes under the `Economics' heading, but his subject is industrial relations.

PARA.TAB: A lot of people write about industrial relations. Industrial relations is a distinct discipline. It ought to be treated within the parameters of that discipline. I am not saying that economists, lawyers and social scientists should not have something to say about industrial relations, but it is important to remember that ultra-dry economists dealing with industrial relations have fundamental problems. Ultra-dry economists have a fundamental problem in dealing with industrial relations because they do not understand human behaviour and human aspirations. They are unable to answer the subjective question that is central to industrial relations: what is fair? They have economic theory. In their case, if real life does not imitate theory, real life is out of step and theory is right, people should change to conform with theory. That is the first error that Dr Wood committed in his article.

The other errors Dr Wood committed are that he supports the New Zealand industrial relations model; he is prejudiced about trade unions; and he has a lopsided view of the facts in the APPM dispute. Even though he criticises APPM for letting down the Right of the political spectrum in Australia for being too fascist in its behaviour, that is because in real life even APPM does not conform with his theory.

There are two other key parts to what Dr Wood has said. Firstly, he supports the Liberal industrial relations policy to bypass trade unions and scrap the Industrial Relations Commission. Secondly, he condemns the Liberal Premier of Tasmania, Ray Groom, for not conforming to theory. In the first part, Dr Wood asks this rhetorical question that John Howard has constantly asked: what is wrong with an employer dealing directly with an employee? He asks what can possibly be wrong with that. Anyone who watches the top rating ABC television program The Investigators will know that people dealing with big or small corporations or shysters do not always get treated fairly. Some of those consumer developments can be transposed into the industrial relations situation.

But if we want to ask whether there can be fair dealing, let us consider power shares and the balance of negotiating shares in this situation. On one side is the right to hire, fire, promote, demote, transfer direct and control access in part to training and all the resources to conduct negotiation. On the other side is someone who needs a job, who may have some skill to market and who has limited resources to bargain. That is why people join trade unions. The industrial relations system exists in order to referee the behaviour of both sides to get an outcome which is good and fair. That applies to unions if they monster small employers as well as applying to employers who might monster small workers.

I now turn to the Ray Groom question. Ray Groom has apparently committed the sin of saying that he recognises there is a role for trade unions; that APPM should come to the table, sit down and talk to them to settle the dispute; that the ACTU President, Mr Martin Ferguson, is a man of principle; that the H.R. Nicholls Society should butt out of the issue in Tasmania; and that politicians driven by ideology do not succeed in politics. They are apparently the mistakes of Ray Groom. That is why Dr Wood has turned his guns on Mr Groom.

Dr Wood has criticised Mr Groom for not being intellectually gifted because he does not understand the Wood theory of economics. He thinks that Mr Groom should back the dry economic theorists in Dr Hewson and Mr Howard so that life can imitate theory. Even though Mr Groom is the elected Premier of Tasmania trying to manage a situation of great complexity and difficulty there, Dr Wood thinks that he should line up behind the ultra-dry conservative industrial relations policies of the Opposition.

I conclude this answer by saying that just this week Dr Hewson, no doubt ably abetted and supported by Mr Howard, delivered a body blow to Tasmania in causing the rejection of the resource security Bill in this chamber. Dr Wood is asking that Ray Groom do to industrial relations what the Opposition has done here to resource security: destroy the industrial relations system. It is about time that the theorists got off their theoretical wavelength and joined real life, and it is about time Dr Hewson and Mr Howard actually came out and endorsed the Liberal Premier of Tasmania and his industrial relations policies and enabled him to resolve the issues that exist within that State. I hope they come out and say, `We support Ray Groom'.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Considering the three very limited concessions given by the State Law and Order Restoration Council in Burma in releasing 48 political prisoners, allowing Suu Kyi to see her husband and allowing refugees on the border to return so long as they can substantiate their nationality, I ask the Minister: does the Government have any deeper or more significant reasons for lessening the pressure on SLORC, as suggested by his comments earlier in the week regarding halting moves towards trade sanctions? If so, what are they?

—We are still waiting for the situation in Burma to become a little clearer. We have had a total of 48 political prisoners now released. We have had the visit permitted, as Senator Chamarette said, to Daw Aung San Suu Kyi by her husband. It is the case that Burmese authorities are still adhering to a cease-fire against the Karen forces near the Thai-Burma border. The assessment we make is one of taking only very cautious encouragement from these announcements. The crucial thing will be whether there is within the next few weeks some serious move towards actually establishing the working conference based on the elected members at the recent election in order to see whether there is some discernible process towards putting in train a democratic reformation.

PARA.TAB: The only point that I was concerned to make the other day is that in the environment that we are now looking at, which is ambiguous—it may be merely cosmetic but it may represent a return to the momentum that did seem to be being established in 1990—it is obviously not only perhaps inappropriate but also likely to be extremely counterproductive to try to encourage a coalition of other countries to take more robust action than is being taken at the moment.

We are still actively discussing questions such as an arms embargo around the corridors of the UN. We still have very much within our sights the possibility of some kinds of economic sanctions if international response can be mobilised to that effect. The point is that nobody will be very keen to embark on any major new initiative in this respect when the situation is as I have described it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I appreciate that response. However, the statement that was made can be discouraging to those people who are concerned about the situation. Why is the Government not choosing this time to maintain or increase pressure on SLORC, because we have had some results, in order to achieve the release of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and all political prisoners to allow the National League for Democracy to convene the Assembly, draft a constitution and hold a referendum to ensure the support of the people in Burma? That is, why do we not use this time strategically to increase pressure rather than talking about decreasing it?

—I am not talking about decreasing pressure; I am simply talking about putting on hold any efforts to increase pressure in a more overt way than has been the case so far. I have been extremely active on this issue, including in China as recently as three weeks or so ago, making a very strong pitch to both Premier Li Peng and, more particularly, Foreign Minister Qian Qichen about the role and responsibilities of China in relation to Burma, describing the country in the process as one run by an ugly regime in a situation that was manifestly at that stage getting uglier with each passing week, and with the situation being created where it appeared that China was the country's only remaining international friend as well as being a substantial supplier of arms that were being used by the Burmese regime against its own people. Whether it is in any way coincidental that a week or so after that we see the course of events that are happening in Burma, I do not know. I cannot judge that.

PARA.TAB: But the kind of representation that I was making to clearly what is one of the key influential countries so far as Burma is concerned is the kind of representation that is being made and has been made in recent months by a number of other countries that share our concern. Sometimes pressure is best applied not so much through the more public vehicles that might attract more obvious notoriety but through back room diplomacy and representations of that kind. We are not in any way reducing the pressure. We are not in any way applauding what has happened. So far as we know, there are still nearly 2,000 political prisoners in custody and an absolutely appalling track record. It will take a lot more to change the reputation of that regime.

—Will the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade comment on reported difficulties in the implementation of the Cambodian peace settlement, including a new outbreak of fighting in Kompong Thom province, delays in the deployment of UN troops and the return of repatriated Cambodians to the camps along the Thai border?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy, as always, to brief the Parliament on the current situation on the ground in Cambodia, and to do so as best I can without talking the situation either up or down apropos of comments from the Leader of the Opposition on radio this morning. It is in nobody's interest to distort the realities of the picture as it presently stands.

PARA.TAB: We are still trying to put together a detailed picture of what happened over the last couple of days in Kompong Thom. Obviously there was a significant breach of the cease-fire by the Khmer Rouge. But current indications are that the number of troops involved in the fighting was smaller than first reported. The Secretary-General's representative, Mr Akashi, said in New York last evening Australian time that the fighting was not on a major scale. Lieutenant-Colonel Ayling, the commander of the Australian force communications unit, said on ABC radio in a direct interview just a couple of hours ago that nothing had happened which will endanger the forward momentum of the peace process—and that does seem to reflect the general view that is prevailing now in Phnom Penh, although the incident is being taken seriously.

Kompong Thom has always been one of the most volatile areas in Cambodia. A further outbreak of military action, although we had all hoped otherwise, was not totally unexpected. That is especially so in the context of the deadline that is getting very close for the announcement, as Lieutenant-Colonel Ayling said, of the phase two aspect of the peace process—that is to say, the introduction of a verified cease-fire as compared with the presently unverified one—and the commencement of the process of cantonment and disarmament.

There is no doubt that the Khmer Rouge have again been misbehaving in Kompong Thom and that they deserve censure on this occasion as previously. But there are a couple of further points to be made. The first is that discussions are taking place right now, as I understand it, with senior Khmer Rouge leadership in Phnom Penh in an attempt to find a lasting solution to the problem in Kompong Thom province. The problems relating to that are a mixture, going among other things to problems with the chain of leadership authority in the NADK, the Khmer Rouge army; problems with the apparent inability of the commanders or the military liaison people on the spot to make detailed decisions of a prompt and effective kind; and also problems associated with the degree of indiscipline by the local Khmer Rouge commanders. Again, the Supreme National Council at its meeting scheduled for tomorrow will, I am told, be considering the situation in Kompong Thom as a major agenda item.

The other point to be made is that the deployment of the whole UN peacekeeping operation is still only in its very early stages and that the dynamics of the imposition of UN authority, the confidence building that goes with that, and the respect for the settlement process that will, we believe, go with that, will not really be able to be fully established until we are further down the deployment track.

As I have stressed on many occasions on behalf of the Government, it is vitally important that the deployment of all the UN personnel, that is the nearly 16,000 troops plus the 5,000 or 6,000 other civilian personnel that will eventually be required, needs to be completed as soon as possible; in particular, the deployment needed to implement the process of cantonment and demobilisation of the 200,000 or so troops that are involved in that process—not half a million, the figure that was used again on ABC radio this morning. We therefore welcome the announcement made yesterday our time by Mr Akashi that UN troops originally intended to be transported by sea will now be airlifted to Cambodia and that, by this means, the UN intends to increase the current number of 4,000 troops in Cambodia to a total of 11,450 by 2 June.

It is in this context of an accelerated deployment, and also in the context of the inability of the UN to quickly get access to the logistics expertise it needs to accomplish that deployment, that Australia positively responded to the urgent request that we received from the UN a few days ago to provide an interim movement control unit to assist in that deployment process, the subject of the announcement by Senator Ray in Parliament yesterday. I repeat Senator Ray's advice, that the 30 personnel concerned will be required by the UN for a period of just four months; it is not a permanent deployment. It is a deployment in order to accelerate the process of implementing troops on the ground.
A number of problems have been shown up by the repatriation process so far.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, this is ridiculous. The Minister can make a statement.

—Nonetheless, the process is well under way; it is being reshaped as it goes. The particular situation in Kompong Thom has led to some reprogramming of that. All I wanted to say about that and the other aspects of the settlement process has been well said by Mr Akashi in a detailed briefing given in New York yesterday our time. I seek leave to incorporate the full text of that briefing in Hansard which I have made available to the Leader of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: PRESS BRIEFING BY SPECIAL REPRESENTATIVE FOR CAMBODIA

At a press briefing at Headquarters this afternoon, Yasushi Akashi, Special Representative of the Secretary-General for Cambodia, provided correspondents with an update on recent events regarding implementation of the mandate of the United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia (UNTAC).

Mr Akashi said he had travelled to Phnom Penh on 15 March, when deployment of UNTAC had begun, and had been accompanied by almost all senior officials, as well as the Force Commander, Lieutenant-General John M. Sanderson of Australia. Since then, a solid United Nations presence had been established in all domains.

The first progress report on the Authority, which was not due until 1 June, would be sent by the Secretary-General to the Security Council in the next day or two, he continued. The report was being sent to the Council in advance of its due date in light of substantial developments, such as the Secretary-General's visit to Cambodia, from 18 to 20 April.

PARA.TAB: The UNTAC was not a peace-keeping operation in the narrow sense of the term; it was a multidimensional and complex operation involving peace-keeping, peace-making and peace-building, Mr Akashi said. The Authority would comprise a civil administration component, in which it had oversight and control functions over the four factions; human rights oversight responsibilities, in view of tragic past events in Cambodia; a component charge with the maintenance of law and order, in view of such factors as insecurity and banditry; and a component charged with the repatriation of refugees.

Mr Akashi went on to say that he had been present, along with Prince Norodom Sihanouk, when the repatriation of refugees from the Thai border commenced on 30 March. Subsequently, repatriation had been suspended for the Cambodian New Year and later resumed. It would be an "uphill task" to complete the return of some 370,000 refugees by the target date of the end of December, but that target had not been changed. He said the Secretary-General had, while in Cambodia, issued an international appeal for the rehabilitation of that country, whose physical infrastructure had been almost completely destroyed over the past two decades. The aggregate amount of rehabilitation assistance required for Cambodia was $593 million, including $160 million for the refugee component.

The UNTAC was not only the largest United Nations peace-keeping operation in history, it was also uniquely multidimensional, he continued. The Authority was responsible for organising democratic and fair elections, which were scheduled to take place in April or early May of next year. Despite certain delays in the deployment of both military and civilian elements, Mr Akashi said he was confident that elections would be held in the anticipated time-frame.

It would be necessary to accelerate the deployment of various troops as well as civilians in order to adhere to the target of beginning phase II of the cease-fire—the "verified cease-fire"—by 1 June, he continued. Many troops which were originally intended to be transported by sea would be airlifted in order to meet that deadline. In June, the rainy season would begin and would considerably hinder UNTAC's movements. For that reason, deployment of the Authority's major elements should take place by the end of May, in order to verify the cease-fire and start the cantonment and demobilisation of up to 70 per cent of troops of the four factions, numbering some 200,000. The Secretary-General's original proposal for 52 cantonment sites had been revised to 55.

There had been intermittent fighting in the north-central province of Kompong Thom, where troops of the four factions were mingled, he went on. The Authority had largely succeeded in restoring the cease-fire and disengaging the factional troops from each other through deployment of two companies of an Indonesian battalion to Kompong Thom. Mr Akashi said he had received a telephone report this morning that fighting had resumed in that province, adding that he did not think fighting was on a "major scale".

The United Nations presence had had a reassuring impact on the population as a whole, he said. The UNTAC had established a good working relationship with the Supreme National Council (SNC) and its head, Prince Sihanouk, who had been responsible, dynamic and helpful. Following close consultations with Prince Sihanouk, it was decided that the Authority would largely propose the agenda of meetings of SNC. A recent proposal had been draft electoral laws, which were currently being discussed.

The Authority had also proposed a new mechanism to investigate human rights violations and take corrective action if necessary, as authorised by the Paris Accords of 23 October 1991. A hotline had been established connecting the Special Representative, the Force Commander and representatives of the four factions. Another proposal, which had been accepted, was the establishment of subsidiary bodies of SNC, called technical advisory committees, to address the details of issues such as rehabilitation assistance and refugee repatriation.

Mr Akashi said he was pleased that the Authority's initial deployment had been favourably received. Despite, or perhaps because of, adverse physical work conditions, the staff was in good spirits and had a high morale. The Advisory Committee on Administrative and Budgetary Questions (ACABQ) would commence its consideration of the Authority's revised, six-month budget on Wednesday.

Flora Lewis had written an opinion piece in today's New York Times on mines in Cambodia, he continued. Mines were certainly a serious concern in that country, as they were sometimes made of plastic and wood and were thus undetectable by traditional means. Trained dogs were assisting in mine detection, which was labour-intensive and time-consuming. Mine-clearance would determine the amount of land which would be available for returnees, and was therefore being given high priority.

A Cambodian Mine Action Centre had been established with SNC and UNTAC sharing the Centre's responsibilities, he said. Prince Sihanouk would be its President and Mr Akashi its Vice-President. The Centre would serve as a vehicle for financial contributions from donor countries. Some 5,000 Cambodians had been trained in mine-clearance, and would de-mine their country. Mine-clearance would be carried out for years and even decades to come.

In response to a question, Mr Akashi said UNTAC was a necessary bridge connecting the four factions, and it was an important catalyst leading to democracy. The Authority was a guarantor of domestic peace and tranquillity during the fragile transitional period.

Asked about the cooperation of the Khmer Rouge, Mr Akashi said the forthcoming report of the Secretary-General would touch on that subject. There had been a positive change in the attitude of the Khmer Rouge, which had stated on 20 April that UNTAC could visit five areas under its control on certain designated dates. That development had been welcome, but the Authority would not be satisfied until it had unconditional access at all times to all areas.

The initial assessed budget for the Authority had been $1.9 billion for its entire mandate, the Special Representative said in reply to another question. Last week, following a review of the assessed budget, it had been reduced to slightly less than $1.8 billion, not including funds for repatriation and rehabilitation, which would be raised on a voluntary basis. The budget would be reassessed for the second six-month period.

Mr Akashi said there were currently 4,000 troops deployed in Cambodia, including a significant air contingent from France, a communications unit from Australia, two infantry battalions from Malaysia and Indonesia, as well as two engineering battalions from China and Thailand, among others. Other units were on their way. Approximately 200 civilian police had been deployed. The civilian police target was 3,600. The Authority sought full deployment of 15,600 troops by June.

Where was Pol Pot? a correspondent asked. Mr Akashi said he had no information in that regard. He had never met Pol Pot; he was regularly in touch with two senior officials of that faction, including General Son San. There was speculation that Pol Pot might be on the Thai-Cambodian border.

To a question on contributions, Mr Akashi said Sadako Ogata, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), said she had received pledges of $60 million for the repatriation effort. Towards the end of June, there would be a conference in Tokyo on Cambodian recovery, which would be co-chaired by the Japanese Foreign Minister, Michio Watanabe, and William H. Draper III, Administrator of the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP). Mr Akashi said he and Prince Sihanouk would attend the opening session of the meeting, which would be held at the ministerial level. Organisers were "pretty confident" that the conference would identify adequate financial support for Cambodian rehabilitation needs. Much work remained to be done. The Asian Development Bank last week took an important positive decision in Hong Kong with regard to aiding Cambodia, he added.

Mr Akashi said he hoped that, in a week or two, it would be possible to publish the report of the recent mission on the economic and financial situation in Cambodia, which would contain recommendations on how to cope with over-expenditure and lack of revenues in the Government. That had been an inter-agency mission, involving UNDP, the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD) the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank. Such coordination was of the utmost importance.

Asked about United States compliance with approval of the Authority's budget, the Special Representative said he would be travelling to Washington, DC, on Wednesday, to meet with Congressional leaders and State as well as Defense Department representatives. He said he generally felt that those leaders and representatives were largely satisfied with the work of UNTAC, which was necessary to the establishment of peace, national reconciliation and democracy so badly needed in Cambodia.

The views of several Member States had been taken into account and had resulted in the reduction of the number of computers required for the elections process, he said. The Authority sought to be as economical as possible, but in order to be credible, a minimum presence was required. Hardly any physical infrastructure existed in Cambodia, the roads were in bad shape, bridges had been destroyed and airports were badly damaged. The Authority's engineering units were repairing and sometimes constructing the country's infrastructure. The budget, which might have seemed large, was not, in view of those needs. The per capita income of Cambodians was estimated to be $100 per year, which was half that of Viet Nam and less than one tenth that of Thailand.

In response to another question, Mr Akashi said the visit to China by SNC representatives had not impeded work. He had been in touch with Prince Sihanouk by fax at the time. China had been very helpful in inviting SNC members to Beijing, and had dealt with the four factions in an even-handed manner, demonstrating its will for the implementation of the Paris Accords. The trip had not been a waste of time; press criticisms of it had been too harsh.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only point I make in conclusion, because I did think that this was a subject of immense interest to people on all sides of the chamber, is that the UN operation is of unprecedented scale and complexity. INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 6 May, from Senator Crane:

PARA.TAB: Dear Mr President,

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to standing order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move that, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The necessity for preserving the existing contracting system as an integral part of employment in many industries, because it is:

PARA.TAB: b)allows legal redress ensuring quality work
c)lowers costs to business

INTERJECT.PARA: and should be further promoted and expanded in its current form to help Australian industry become internationally competitive, not restricted as proposed by the Minister for Industrial Relations.

PARA.TAB: Senator for Western Australia

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

PARA.TAB: The necessity for preserving the existing contracting system as an integral part of employment in many industries, because it is:

SPEECH.PARA: a)efficient and highly productive

PARA.TAB: b)allows legal redress ensuring quality work
c)lowers costs to business

SPEECH.PARA: and should be further promoted and expanded in its current form to help Australian industry become internationally competitive, not restricted as proposed by the Minister for Industrial Relations.

The reason for moving this urgency motion in the Senate today is that the most efficient and productive method of getting work done in Australia is under threat. That method is the current contract system. It is under threat because a company known as Troubleshooters, which had initiative or what is commonly known as get-up-and-go, established a contract system that would improve the output of the work force in this country, and the efficiency and productivity of many industries; put more profit into business; and, most importantly, increase the take-home pay of individuals.

PARA.TAB: The proposals of the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook—

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is he?

—That is a good question. Where is he? The proposals which have been widely circulated to industry are being run under the guise of tackling the issue of sham contractors. This is nonsense. Their position is already protected in law through the Trade Practices Act. Secondly, it is protected by the individuals themselves who do not have to enter into a contract. The proposals have wide reaching ramifications for industry. They will lead to lower productivity and huge increases in cost, and will be damaging to the Australian economy.

PARA.TAB: The current contract system has stood the test of time in almost every industry one can mention, the most notable being the housing or cottage industry, agriculture, mining, transport and, of course, a myriad of others. The current system allows individuals to actually assess a task by using their initiative and wit and then get on with doing the job as quickly and as efficiently as possible. It allows them to maximise their skills and increase their capacity to increase their own income. It has served Australia well and will continue to do so providing that the Government, the unions and the Australian Industrial Relations Commission keep out of the way. If the system is changed, as the Minister advocates, it will increase disputation, remove flexibility and interfere with the rights of individuals to freely determine how they are going to operate.

The Minister consistently runs the line that change is necessary because of sham contractors. The fact is that we now have a sham Minister who is an apologist for certain elements in the trade union movement in this country, in particular the Building Workers Industrial Union. The evidence shows quite clearly that the instructions to change the current contract system have come about as a result of the Troubleshooters case which was heard before Justice Woodward of the Federal Court, then the full bench of the Federal Court and, finally, the High Court of Australia.

Following the High Court decision on 7 June 1991, just 11 months ago, the Minister—or, should I say, the apologist for the trade union movement—described the law as an ass. Not only does he not accept the decisions of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission when they do not suit him, but he is now moving to undermine the decisions of the Federal Court and the High Court of this country because their decisions do not suit his union masters and their hidden agenda, which is to increase union membership and union domination at the expense of a proven system of efficiency and productivity.
To prove this point I quote from a letter of 4 May 1990 by Tom McDonald, the National Secretary of the Builders Workers Industrial Union. In that letter, amongst other things, Mr McDonald stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Past experience shows that where workers work as self-employed subcontractors, it is impossible to effectively unionise or organise those workers. That is why the New Right is pushing the self-employed subcontract arrangements.
Mr McDonald further stated:

The trade union movement must close ranks to ensure that this type of agreement does not become a precedent for the introduction of enterprise bargaining which is not underpinned by the award wage and conditions of employment.

I quote from a letter from Mr Vince Raffa, Secretary of the Victorian Branch of the BWIU, which was sent to every member of the union. The letter stated two things. It stated firstly that, because of the union's loss in courts and subsequent damages paid to Troubleshooters, each and every member was to be levied to pay. Secondly, and more importantly, Mr Raffa stated:

We have also been vindicated by the fact that the Federal Government has announced its intention to pass legislation making Troubleshooters Available type arrangements illegal by changing the Federal Industrial Relations Act.

It is interesting to note that at least the Victorian Branch of the BWIU knew about this some two months before it was announced publicly.I quote from a document from Stephen Rothman from HB Higgins Chambers. This was a legal opinion prepared for the BWIU. Amongst other things, that document states:

There would also need to be a definition of the word `employee' in the following terms: employee means a person engaged under a Contract of Service (as defined) and employment has a corresponding meaning.

This is the true agenda of what the proposed legislation is about and the attempts to destroy the current contracting system. Almost every industry has rejected the decision to bring contractors under the jurisdiction of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Are their opinions to be ignored? Are they not important?

PARA.TAB: The Minister has released a paper entitled,`Legislation Concerning the Independent Contractors'. The Minister has claimed that legitimate contractors—whatever that means—and, in particular, the housing industry, will be quarantined. This is impossible, as legal advice shows. I quote legal advice from Gallons Crowley and Chamberlain. Terry Chamberlain stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed changes are very broad in scope, much broader in fact than Senator Cook has stated publicly. They are in no way limited to sham sub-contractors or to agreements that are harsh or unfair. Certainly they would cover the housing industry, despite the Senator's assurance.
I further quote:
Disputes about Independent Contractors

Under the proposal, the definition of industrial dispute is to be amended to encompass disputes extending beyond the limits of any one state about the use or proposed use of independent contractors instead of employees to perform work.

Under this definition the jurisdiction of the AIRC is virtually limitless with regard to independent contractors. There is no quarantine for any particular industry or any particular subject of dispute.
I quote further from the same document. Under the heading `Union Membership' it states:

An independent contractor is by definition an independent businessman and entitled to employ others in the conduct of his business. Properly he should be represented by an employer association such as the HIA but lodgement of union membership for such a contractor is weak, although the motive is clear, that is, to extend union domain. However, in terms of representation, such a move would establish the subcontractor as a schizophrenic represented by and yet a potential supplicant to an adversary of union and union demands.

PARA.TAB: Further, I go on to quote from the same document:

SPEECH.PARA: If, as Senator Cook states, the sole reason for the changes is to catch sham arrangements or unjust contracts, then the proposals are wholly unnecessary for the following reasons:
1. First, if the concern is to save contractors from themselves and to regulate unjust contracts, recourse can be had to the Trade Practices Act.
So it is already covered in law. It goes on:
2. Secondly, if the concern is to catch sham arrangements designed to avoid Award provisions, these arrangements are in fact already caught up by the existing Act.
The conclusion is very interesting. In part it says:

The proposed changes are essentially unnecessary to the extent they are proposed as a basis for regulating sham arrangements and unjust contracts. What they really represent is a hidden agenda for increased union power.

PARA.TAB: I now move to another legal opinion, this one prepared by Taylor, Zeckley and Kelso, from which I will give only one quote. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed legislation will allow unions to be—
and listen to this—

for the first time involved in respect of the building industry in contract negotiations where issues such as retention sums, liquidated damages, contract interpretation, rising and fall clauses, time claims and other important but not industry-orientated provisions.

This decision of the Government to interfere with the very efficient and productive system that operates in this country has far reaching ramifications. It is best summarised by Mr Geoff Wedgwood, Housing Industry Association economist, who said:
If commercial building practices are enforced on the residential industry, costs would increase by 20 to 25 per cent.

Legal advice shows quite clearly this will happen. This decision will make every industry in this country less competitive; it will remove initiative and interfere with the freedom of individuals to choose; it will mean business profits will drop, consumer prices will rise, and an individual's capacity to maximise his or her earnings will be reduced.

PARA.TAB: This is a fundamental test not only of the Minister to put Australia's efficiency and productivity first—and I might add, the Government's—but also of the Democrats to determine whether they wish to see building costs, housing costs, mining costs and farming costs go up; in fact, the full spectrum of all costs going up in this country and our being left less competitive—and, I might add, with disputation going up. It will have ramifications for every household because it will put enormous pressure on inflation and, of course, on almost every product and service they require.

The proposed legislation is a sham. It will destroy the current contract system. It is designed to further increase union power. As I have already said, the current contract system in this country has evolved through the test of time and has served us well. The basis for the Government's proposed changes are flawed, as shown by the legal opinion. They are already covered by law—by the Trade Practices Act and the current Australian Industrial Relations Act.

If the Government does not recognise that the current system is serving us well, then not only are its proposals a sham but, as I have claimed in my opening statements, it also has a sham Minister for Industrial Relations, who is an apologist to the trade union movement and could not give a damn about the opinions of industry. The current contract system should be promoted and encouraged—not undermined and destroyed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I was quite interested in Senator Crane's proposal that he wants unions and governments to get out of the way. He wants to put that proposal into effect to give free rein to shonky subcontractors to deny workers justice and a real future in an important industry in this country. Press releases issued by the Master Builders Association on 1 April included figures that were totally incorrect. Neither that organisation nor the Housing Industry Association contacted the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) about the Government's proposals and consequently they have got things dead wrong.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that no genuine contractor or employer using contactors will be affected by this proposal. Housing costs will not soar, as is claimed by those organisations. We are not touching the present arrangements in the industry relating to genuine subcontractors. The legislation is aimed solely at sham contractors; people who call themselves contractors and work as employees for lower pay or without basic rights such as annual leave, sick leave, superannuation and occupational health and safety considerations. We propose that the Australian Industrial Relations Commission will have regard to relevant customs and practices in a dispute over independent contractors and ensure that their use is not harsh or unfair.

The proposed subcontracting legislation is not an attack on the existing contracting system in any industry. There is no agenda from the trade union movement or the Labor Government to attack the legitimate contracting system already operating, as it has for some years. The proposed legislation is designed to eliminate specific, obnoxious defects in the contract system in many industries, particularly clothing where tax rorts and the abuse of outworkers is notorious. These defects are exploited unscrupulously by bad operators who threaten the position of legitimate and honest business. The urgency motion can be read only as an attempt to promote and expand these obnoxious defects in their current form.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a load of rubbish.

—The Opposition's motion is rubbish. The proposed legislation will provide the opportunity for subcontract workers to seek and achieve justice. The legislation is aimed particularly at harsh and unfair contracts and sham contractors. It will have no effect on genuine contracts or the efficiency, productivity, quality and costs of genuine contract agreements in any industry. We will provide subcontractors with an efficient means to seek redress where they have been exploited, and to recover moneys owing to them.

PARA.TAB: We have heard the comment that there are situations that already provide for this. I will give some examples—some case histories. A worker was employed by company W from November 1991 through to and including 11 March 1992. He was told that his status during this period of employment was that of a legitimate subcontractor and he was paid $20 per hour. A prescribed payments system of taxation was applied. Upon lodging the complaint, he indicated that at no time did he want to work under this system. The company had told him that unless he worked by this method there was no employment for him.

That is conscription; employers forcing people to work under these sorts of conditions. The union approached the company in April 1992 and reached the following agreement: that all BUS and BERT contributions for his period of employment would be paid; the company would also pay the award provisions that the member did not receive—$1,000 in travelling time and fares, $1,500 pro rata annual leave, $640 for statutory holidays and rostered days off, a total of $6,000 in four months. That is what the worker was denied.

In another case person B was employed from 22 March 1988 to mid-1992—a longer period. He was paid and taxed under the prescribed payments system. During his period of employment he received no annual leave, no award allowances, no BUS or BERT—BERT being the Building Employees Retirement Trust—contributions and no other entitlements as per the award. The union approached the company in April 1992. A discussion with regard to taxation took place on site between a union official and person B. This is important—this is these honest contractors. Person B informed the official that during the four years that he had been employed by this company, and taxation had been deducted under the PPS, the employer had not forwarded any of these payments to the Australian Taxation Office. So much for these wonderfully honest and thoughtful people to whom Senator Crane referred. They are trying to introduce and maintain a system which exploits workers.

The union immediately stopped all work on the project and sat down to negotiations with the company. At the end of the negotiations, the following agreement was reached: the company would pay all outstanding taxation contributions which should have been paid—a sum of $46,500 which it had nobbled the Taxation Office for to that stage. In addition, it signed a statutory declaration saying that it accepted all liabilities for any fines and penalties placed upon person B. That indemnified person B against any prosecution by the Australian Taxation Office for the company's wrongdoing.

In addition, the company would pay the member a sum of $15,000 for those award entitlements he did not receive during his period of employment. The hourly rate received by this person over the employment period fluctuated between $14 per hour and $20 per hour. They are just two examples and there are others. For instance, in Queensland there is an agreement called the resilient floor layers agreement. It covers rates of pay for carpet layers and resilient floor layers. Person C was working under award rates of pay during his period of employment with two companies. This person was employed for some time by both companies and towards the end of the employment was elevated to the status of supervisor.

In short, the person was never paid in accordance with the agreement. He was also forced to provide his own accommodation and transportation when sent into country areas. He did not receive BUS or BERT contributions or any other entitlements that would have applied under the award. The union placed bans and limitations to get the employer to the negotiating table. So much for these agreements and the subcontractors who will do wonderfully well out of them. Employers have to be forced to comply with payments through industrial disputes that nobody wants. The final result was that the sum of $15,000 was agreed between the parties to be paid to the worker after some deductions had been made.

They are just three stated examples. They are specific cases, not this airy-fairy stuff of somebody's legal opinion—though legal opinions are important. The Queensland branch of the union which negotiated these recoveries estimated that, out of approximately $1.5m recovered for members, 40 per cent of the cases were similar to those three cases. Many other cases would not see the light of day.

An important point for the Australian Democrats to consider is that the genuine subcontractors who will benefit from the provisions of this legislation are small business people. The Democrats see them as part of their constituencies. They are now effectively denied redress because their only appeal against abuse of the contract system is through the civil law system. That road leads to huge delays and massive costs. It is no answer. There is no effective redress under the Commonwealth jurisdiction.
I believe that a recent contract has been offered to people in Tasmania. This was also dealt with by some legal analysis. One particular clause says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . it is clear that the contractor has full liability for all damage however arising to the company, its officers, employees or agents which arises out of the performance of the services.

For example, if the contractor provides some services and for some unforeseeable reason one of the company's employees is injured in an accident which is in some way connected with the provision of those services the contractor would be solely liable to the company employee regardless of whether that contractor is liable in negligence.

A further example of the far-reaching effects of the clause is that, if a contractor provides services and for some unforeseeable reason the employee of another contractor of the company is injured for whatever reason which is in some way connected with the services provided, the contractor would be liable to that other contractor's employee, regardless of whether he was liable in negligence or otherwise. So much for the protection that people get. Employees get protection under normal working conditions under an award.

PARA.TAB: I now go to the issue of the housing section. There is nothing new in these proposals; they already exist in many States. Many building licensing boards have introduced various forms of tribunals to resolve disputes between builders and subcontractors over payments and moneys owing. Even the Greiner Government in its industrial relations legislation left intact the provisions for a similar tribunal in New South Wales.

The trade union movement and the Labor Government are committed to an economy which operates with the optimum of efficiency and with world-class standards of performance. This is the basis of the micro-economic reform agenda being pursued by the Government. As an example, examine the efficiency of the commercial building sector. By world standards it is highly efficient, but under the construction industry development strategy the Commonwealth and the States are working with industry and unions to further improve results. They are not satisfied. They are sitting down doing something about it, not suggesting the continuation of some system that will destroy that opportunity for a better future.

Levels of productivity performance in the Australian industry over the last 20 years have been substantially above the OECD average. The average annual increase in productivity in Australian construction has been 2.58 per cent compared with an OECD average of 1.75 per cent. Compare the Australian industry's effort with West Germany's 2.04 per cent; the UK at 1.75 per cent; or the US—whose labour market practices the Opposition wants to emulate—at a figure of 0.45 of one per cent. So much for the constructive views of the Opposition. Yet in this industry performance is excellent compared with international trends—

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you repeat those figures? I didn't understand them.

—Senator Brownhill got them all right. Yet in this industry where performance is excellent compared with international trends, further co-operative effort—great effort—is being made to bring about further improvements. Substantial progress has been made under the newly created construction industry reform strategy through unprecedented consultation and agreement between government at State and Commonwealth levels, industry and unions. All parties to this strategy are confident that it will lead to further reform.

PARA.TAB: Only this morning I was talking to an officer of a very large construction company about this legislation. He made points to me that I believe are fairly sensible and intelligent. He said that the Government is seeking to avoid exploitation of loopholes in the arrangements between employees and employers as they genuinely stand. While a lot can be said about the cost of labour, I would point out that it is at a figure of about 25 per cent in some areas, and down to 15 per cent in others.

The important relationship in the industry is between the client and the main contractor, between the contractor and the subcontractors and between employer and employees. This is a long term relationship and it promises to be more productive than has been the case in the past. It is about the production process—productivity improvements, total quality management and training—so that we can equate with the clever country. I have been in the trade union movement a long time and I do not know of any subcontractors—subcontractors of the type that Senator Crane seeks to defend—who have ever trained anybody in the industry; if they did, it was probably for a couple of days to do a particular job so that they could make a larger profit.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do they do their jobs if they are not trained?

—They very often do not; the position has to be rectified and there are legal arguments about it. This is a mature relationship and will not be based on bastardised subcontracting. Most, if not all, construction companies will clearly say that the current system is competitive and future markets will require cutting through bad management and bad work practices. As I have already indicated, that has been done through the system of cooperation between the various parties in the industry.

PARA.TAB: The strategy I spoke of recognises that effective improvements in productivity, efficiency and cost saving needs to concentrate on the issues of industry development, training and skills development, as well as industrial relations. Enterprise bargaining principles are being incorporated into the industry's operations. An agreement has already been struck with Concrete Constructions, resulting in significant improvements in productivity and efficiency—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what it is designed to do, to take the contractor out.

—But Senator Crane would not want to know that. He does not want to know about the good things in the industry such as increased productivity and other improvements. All he wants to know about are the negative and bad things. Negotiations are well in advance for agreements with Civil and Civic and Lend Lease and have begun with many other companies. That is a fairly good accomplishment.

PARA.TAB: A simple way of looking at issues such as this is to use a question and answer process. We may ask the question: will the legislation change the nature of the contracting system? The answer is no, because those working as genuine independent contractors or subcontractors will still get paid on results, for example, per item, per metre, et cetera, as against an employee who is paid on a time basis. This means that the incentive for productivity will not change.

The next question to be asked is: who will be affected? The answer is: those employers who seek to classify employees as contractors or subcontractors for the purpose of avoiding their legal obligations to their employees and who seek to undermine genuine independent subcontractors who observe their legal obligations to their employees. They are the ones who will be affected most.

That is what it is about—reducing wage rates and reducing the take-home pay for ordinary workers so that more and more profit can go into the coffers of those employers who do not care about the long term future of the industry and this country.

Why is the legislation necessary? That is a good question. Senator Crane suggests that it is not necessary. The answer is: to clarify and give recognition and protection both to both bona fide contractors and to employees, due to the fact that some shonky operators are forcing workers to engage in sham arrangements designed to undermine community standards under the guise of `contracting' or `subcontracting'.

How will it affect costs? It will reduce costs in many instances and will increase costs only where the employer is paying less than the community standard, as determined by the Industrial Relations Commission after hearing all the evidence. Surely people are entitled to a minimum wage for the work that they do.

How will it reduce costs? Senator Crane, and Senator Kemp particularly, would be interested in this. It will produce better quality work which will reduce consumer complaints in regard to shoddy workmanship which leads to higher maintenance costs. How many times, as a result of shoddy workmanship, have we seen cases of a product being delivered and there being no end of problems developing over a period? We seek to build the quality into the building by the use of good practices in terms of training and total quality control. It will allow better training of apprentices, which will protect the long term skill base of the industry. It is an accepted fact that the current system has caused the virtual collapse of the apprenticeship system in the housing industry. The housing industry will have less turnover of labour and will therefore retain a greater number of its skilled personnel.

Where will this measure increase costs? Only where the Industrial Relations Commission determines that the payments are less than community standards. This will protect the legitimate builders and contractors by civilising the shonky operators, as difficult as that may be. Maybe the Opposition believes we should pay anybody as little money as we can get away with. It does not care that people do not have a reasonable living standard for the ones they love and the people around them. It does not care about the community in general getting benefits. It is the distribution of wealth that is important. The Opposition wants to distribute it to the rich people in this country.

The housing industry predicts that the cost of a house will go up by $25,000. The answer to that is that it will not. Research done in past years shows that, of construction costs in the cottage industry, labour represents only 24 per cent. Of the mortgage dollar, labour costs represent only 6 per cent, which includes the cost of finance, land, materials and profit besides labour. Since this research was done, technology has increased, further reducing labour costs while land prices and material prices have generally gone up. The Opposition does not worry about people who buy land and exploit the public by making huge profits out of it as it appreciates in value.

Will this measure increase industrial disputation? That is something the Opposition is always raving on about. No, it will reduce it because it will provide an independent body, the AIRC, to prevent and resolve any disputes. In other words, it will provide an independent forum, instead of the current situation where subcontractors have to either let the shonky builder rob him—and they do—or go to the union and fight it out in the field. But the Opposition wants to destroy the unions so that the workers have no representations. That is its attitude.

Will it increase unionisation? The Opposition will love this answer. No, because similar legislation in different States has not by itself increased unionisation. The legislation might reduce unionisation, as the subcontractors will have somewhere to go—to the Industrial Relations Commission—to resolve their problems whereas now they can only go to the trade unions. Will the legislation give unions the right to recruit subcontractors? Is this legislation new? No, there is similar legislation in many States.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment, which is being circulated at the moment, suggests that the urgency motion be amended to read as follows:

PARA.TAB: Omit all words after `preserving', substitute:

SPEECH.PARA: `some of the existing contracting systems as an integral part of employment in many industries when they:

PARA.TAB: (a)are efficient and highly productive;

TAB.TAB: (b)allow legal redress ensuring quality work; and

SPEECH.PARA: With that slight amendment we would certainly support the urgency motion. We do that because—to take up the suggestion that Senator Macdonald made very early in this debate—not all subcontractors or contractors are sham subcontractors or contractors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macdonald hasn't spoken.

—Senator Macdonald interjected to say that not all contractors were sham contractors. I respond to that by agreeing with him and suggesting that not all contractors are lilywhite. I agree with any of the some 400 letters that I have received on this subject. I read to the Senate part of the second paragraph of one such letter, although any number of builders and subcontractors have written to tell me the same:

SPEECH.PARA: The existing sub-contracting tradition in the building industry is not in any way a "sham", but represents a very important, efficient and productive sector of the industry.

I agree with that, as would Senator Macdonald, with the addition of two words at the front so that it reads, `Most of the existing subcontracting tradition in the building industry is not in any way a sham'. The trouble with the original motion proposed by Senator Crane is that it is an absolute. It has in it the definite article `the' meaning the subcontracting industry in total is a wonderful thing. I can assure him—and I can assure the Senate—that it certainly is not. In making that assurance I will say that the housing industry is characterised by a most efficient and effective system which has grown up in a tradition of `That's the way to do it'. It has become most effective.

PARA.TAB: Some of the reasons for the growth of that tradition are related to the geography of the industry. The very fact that the sites of operation are by definition temporary and located away from each other has meant that individual methods—in other words, independent methods—have grown up to suit the site and location of the enterprise and the individual needs of the owner. Because of that, we have had the development over many decades of what is now in most cases—that is what I am emphasising, `most cases'—a very efficient and productive aspect of Australian industry.

However, not all housing industry participants are lilywhite and not all of those engaged in subcontracting are pure in their business practices. Through the very diversity that I am speaking about—through its geography—the housing industry obviously provides opportunities for unprincipled operators to exploit those who work as contractors. That is as much a result of the size of the industry as well. I must say that the overwhelming majority of traditional operators in the housing industry are efficient in their endeavours and honourable in their commercial and industrial undertakings.I do speak with some degree of personal experience—

TALK.START.PARA: —I was under the impression that I had moved that the urgency motion be amended. Hansard may be able to correct us. The position I had reached was to add some degree of personal experience in this industry, having been directly involved in a number of building projects over a number of years as an employee, owner builder and, coincidentally, right at this very moment, an owner who has engaged a builder who in turn engages subcontractors. All of those subcontractors are thoroughly and efficiently supervised by my wife. She probably knows more about the practicality and the reality of this business than some of the others who might purport to contribute to this debate. Things are going very well indeed.

PARA.TAB: I also speak in this debate as a recipient—one who has been on the receiving end—of what I now know was an unfair contract. It was an employment contract under which, some years ago, I was able to derive the princely sum of $2 an hour to service and maintain a fleet of cars for a hire car firm. Senator Kemp may be surprised to learn that the rate at that time was a very attractive rate, although that was some 20 years ago. Even though it seemed attractive, it did not include sick leave or leave of any description, overtime or any other award benefits.At the time, I was too ignorant to realise what I was setting aside. I did learn very quickly what it was that I had set aside when a car axle fell on my leg. It was simple: I did not get any more money; I did not work any more.

After that incident I learned that the contract was harsh and unfair and it had taken advantage of my ignorance. I did not know, therefore, I did not have any real choice. The word `choice' has already been used in this debate. Senator Crane has suggested, and he would suggest now, that I may have had recourse to the Trade Practices Act. In my ignorance, I remained exploited. No organisations, no body in particular, made it their business to safeguard my interests. I suggest that there remain many other examples of the situation which I suffered at that time. I do not think that in the 20 years since that experience that we have been able to resolve that particular situation.

In fact, it is not restricted to what one would imagine is the traditional semi-skilled, unskilled labouring area.Even such an august body as the South Australian Education Department stands accused of requiring some teachers to work under contracts so that the obligations of that Department as an employer can be avoided. I would also suggest that all one has to do to find further examples of such exploitation is to look and listen to what is happening in the work force.

I have an example here—and this is well documented—of a situation which occurred in 1985. TNT, the transport company, sold a truck to a person and kept the registration in the name of TNT. The company, TNT, decided on the amount of the monthly repayments, made arbitrary deductions from the person's earnings and gave him less and less subcontract work. The truck had been sold on the basis that subcontract work would be made available exclusively to the new truck owner. Once that person was unable to keep up the repayments, guess what? TNT repossessed the vehicle. The contract, of course, was labelled, and found to be, unfair.

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation has no bearing on that and you know it.

—The fact is that such contracts can be examined under the proposed legislation as to whether they are fair, harsh or unconscionable. The person who is being exploited in such a situation will now have recourse to the Industrial Relations Commission being able to examine the contract under those criteria.
—That is not a contract of labour; it is a contract of sale.

—Senator Crane is giving us the benefit of his wisdom. If he thinks the contract of sale in this case was divorced from the actual work situation that the person found himself in then, regardless of Senator Crane's wisdom, the fact is that the negotiations and the contract remained unfair and harsh. Somebody was taken advantage of without having recourse to being defended or represented by somebody who knew the situation. The example I gave of myself was one that grew out of my own ignorance. When one is on one's own there is very little opportunity to do anything about one's ignorance. When one has the opportunity to learn from the experience of others and to be represented by others, that is the strength which comes from unity.

PARA.TAB: There are recent examples of people's ignorance being exploited. I refer to the Indy 500 Gold Coast car race where people who

SPEECH.PARA: wanted to be employed as guard-security officers were given the opportunity to become contractors and be paid a straight $10 an hour flat rate. People jumped at the chance. Here was a big show coming to town and they would be able to earn some quick money. But their ignorance was soon removed when they realised that once they commenced employment, that $10 would be paid each hour, every hour no matter how many hours they worked—whether it was 14 hours at a stretch or not—because there were no breaks, no overtime and no sick leave, just a straight $10 an hour. The net result was something much less than the award rate.

PARA.TAB: A security dog handler was paid $11.20 an hour with his own dog. The award rate is normally $15 an hour. No superannuation was paid to anybody even though there is a legal obligation to do so. This was a situation contrived simply to avoid the obligations that an employer would normally have towards an employee.

Through this urgency motion moved by Senator Crane there is an opportunity to demonstrate that there are opportunities where the subcontracting-contracting system throughout Australia can be congratulated and recognised for being efficient. Some such arrangements are a considerable advantage to Australian industry, but not all. I believe that the forthcoming legislation offers us an opportunity to examine all contractual arrangements and enable those who may have been exploited to remove that exploitation. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit all words after "preserving", substitute:
`some of the existing contracting systems as an integral part of employment in many industries when they:
(a)are efficient and highly productive;
(b)allow legal redress ensuring quality work; and
(c)lower costs to business.'.
