TALK.START.PARA: —I will start at the beginning with the Government's opposition to this urgency motion and come to the Democrats shortly. I was very much taken by Senator Burns's moving and passionate speech in which he talked about harsh and unfair treatment of workers and genuine contractors or employers not being affected by the proposal of the Government. He said that the legislation is aimed solely at sham contractors. That sounded familiar to me. In fact, it sounded rather like a press release that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) put out on, of all days, April Fools' Day, 1 April 1992. It was Senator Burns who was the April Fool and anybody who believes Senator Burns and gets suckered in by this sort of nonsense coming from the Minister for Industrial Relations is the April Fool.

PARA.TAB: The sad fact is that this is nothing more than a cynical exercise at power grabbing by the union bully boys in Australia. Senator Crane made this very clear in his address. He read from a letter written to members of the Victorian Building Workers Industrial Union by Mr Vince Raffa. I repeat a sentence from that letter for the benefit of the Senate and those people who might be listening:

SPEECH.PARA: We have also been vindicated by the fact that the Federal Government has announced its intention to pass legislation making the Troubleshooters Available type arrangements illegal by changing the Federal Industrial Relations Act.

This letter is saying that they were not vindicated by the Federal Court. This matter went to the highest court in the land, right up to the High Court, which said that these arrangements were legal. I will come to the judgment in a second, but the judgment said that these arrangements were also very fair.

PARA.TAB: What is the objection of the union leaders if these arrangements are both legal and fair? The union leaders' objection is not based on the best interests of the worker or of unionists, because everybody who is involved in Troubleshooters Available was a unionist. This is all about a grab for power. They are trying to further strengthen the arm of the union movement and make a mockery of existing arrangements between people in the building industry.

What this proposal from Senator Cook would do is quite frightening. If there is a dispute about the contract terms—and it talks about the erection of a frame for a house or the laying of bricks for a house—instead of that dispute between a contractor and a subcontractor going to a court, it will go to the Industrial Relations Commission. Notwithstanding that the dispute may be about whether the frame was erected in the right place or the bricks were laid in the right fashion, instead of going to a court of law for the dispute to be determined because it is a contract, it will be sent to the Industrial Relations Commission.

Today the people on the other side of the chamber are saying that the Federal Court is not good enough to look after building contracts and does not seem to know enough about building contracts to look after disputes between contractors and subcontractors. Those opposite believe that the whole matter will be sent to the Industrial Relations Commission, notwithstanding the fact that the Industrial Relations Commission does not know a thing about building contracts. That is the problem caused by the lack of logic on the other side of the chamber.

Is it an efficient means of redressing problems to give it all to the Building Workers Industrial Union, when already there is a sanction against harsh and unconscionable contracts under the Trade Practices Act? Also there is State legislation that prohibits unfair contract terms. Yet that is not good enough for the Government. It wants to impose its own unfair contract terms and unfairly oblige everybody involved in the building industry to join a union whether they like it or not. That is what it is all about.

It all boils down to the fact that the Government is trying to get its hands on some more money to bolster its campaign coffers before the next Federal election. The Government is saying, `Let's press-gang some more people and make them unionists so that we have enough money to fight the next Federal election'. That is the effect of this legislation and that is what the Government does not have the courage to tell this chamber today.

I turn now to the Democrats. The members of the coalition are unwilling to accept the Democrat amendment and I will outline why. It takes out the principal portion of Senator Crane's motion, which deals with maintaining the contracting system and keeping it safe from the ravages of the Minister for Industrial Relations. First of all, the Democrats say that they are not willing to keep the existing contracting system but only some of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right—the good ones.

—Senator Bell acknowledges that. The Democrats are going along with the Government and saying, `No. You might live in Australia, but you are not entitled to enter into a contract as you wish. You can do so only if we, Big Brother, allow you to enter into a contract'. That is the first part of what the Democrats are saying. The second thing is that they have deleted the bit at the end of the motion that says that the existing contract system should be further promoted and expanded in its current form to help Australian industry become internationally competitive and not restricted as proposed by the Minister for Industrial Relations. The Democrats' amendment takes all that out.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats are not interested in becoming internationally competitive, not only in the building industry but in any other industry. Worse still, they are clearly not going to stand up to the Minister for Industrial Relations and his legislation. They do not come out and say, `We are going to vote with the Government'. They do not have the courage to say that or to come before the Senate and say, `We will stand by Senator Cook and sink or swim with him'. They want to appear as if they are interested in getting something, but will still go over and stand with Senator Cook, anyway. That is why we feel that the amendment moved by the Democrats is wholly unsatisfactory.

Let us get down to the real crux of this debate or the real unconscionability of what this Government wants to do. For example, a person who is an independent contractor is probably a member of the Housing Industry Association. But if the Government has its way, that person will be forced to be a union member. Quite simply, if a person is a subcontractor, eventually they will be required to become a union member. But it will turn that person into a paranoid schizophrenic, because on one side they will be a member of the HIA and on the other side a member of the Building Workers Industrial Union. Which hat will they put on? It will certainly not be a hard hat because they will be too busy shuffling between the HIA hat and the union hat. They will not even know where to find the hard hat, because the Government is being hard on all the people in this country who want to go out and determine their terms of employment for themselves.

What is so wrong with people having freedom of choice as to how and when they work? What is so offensive to individual liberty about that? Nothing at all, but it offends the sensibilities of Minister Cook and his cronies on the other side of the chamber, who are dreadfully afraid of what it would do to their mates in the union movement. The bottom line is that most Australian workers are heartily sick and tired of the men in suits in the Industrial Relations Commission determining for them how, where and when they will work. If real economic reform is to be achieved in this economy and in making this nation more productive, the only way to do so is by putting the decision making power in the hands of the employers and employees.

If there is any doubt about the ethical righteousness of that, I refer Government members to a speech I heard this morning made by Father Usher, who addressed the Parliamentary Christian Fellowship and who works with the Catholic Social Welfare Council. He said that we need to put more of the decision making power in the hands of the employer and the employee, and that this confrontationist approach that those opposite wish to support is just not on.

The problem is that the Government is so dreadfully afraid of workers being able to determine for themselves how they are going to work. It is so dreadfully afraid that the people who were once kept as minions of the union movement will suddenly have some say or choice in their lives that it has brought in this heinous legislation to take away the rights of those people. I say to Senator Giles, Senator Burns and some of their socialist friends on the other side of the chamber—the revolution is coming, comrades! The revolution is almost upon us, because the real revolution is to put the power in the hands of the workers rather than in the hands of the unions.

That is something the Government has never been able to understand because it has never been able to understand the mentality of the ordinary working man or woman. That is clearly shown in the fact that this is the Government that has put almost one million ordinary men and women out of work. It just does not understand the fact that some people want to work. Some people want to work hard, some people want to be productive and some people do not want to be under the yoke of the union movement. This is nothing more than a cynical ploy to extend the power of Martin Ferguson and Bill Kelty.

We already have the mechanisms in the Trade Practices Act to ensure that there is no exploitation and that there is no harshness, unfairness or unconscionableness. I ask the Government senators sitting opposite: what is wrong with the Federal Court? What is wrong with the High Court? What is wrong with the highest court in the land determining the rights of employers and employees? Instead of having the High Court of Australia, the highest judicial body in this country, Senator Cook and the Government would give us the Clayton's court, the Industrial Relations Commission—and a poor parody of the High Court that is indeed. The Government does not want to have judicial determination. It wants to have determination by the Industrial Relations Commission. If I were in a jam, if I were in a dispute and I wanted a fair, decent and impartial determination of my problem, I would much rather go to the Federal Court or the High Court any day of the week than to the Industrial Relations Commission.

Let us get it very clear to the Government. We on this side of the chamber stick by the judicial system in this country. We are not in for lynch mobs. We stick by the fair, judicial process and by the right of every man and woman in this nation, no matter who they are, where they work or what job they do, to go before a court and have their problems sorted out rather than before some commission, which is basically a sham court.

So let us get down to the basic facts. The Government is dreadfully afraid. It is dreadfully afraid of losing the election. That is why it wants to rush this legislation into place. It is dreadfully afraid of what will happen if people actually get the choice as to whether they are going to be unionists or free people. This Government is dreadfully afraid that the revolution is coming and it is missing out. I put to the Government that, come the glorious day, the people of this country will vote with their feet. They will vote at the ballot box. One thing is for sure: they will vote out this Government, they will vote out Senator Cook and they will vote out this heinous legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —With his usual athleticism, Senator O'Chee has been leaping to conclusions at a great rate. Most of his contribution to this debate has been hardly worth responding to. I do have some regrets in relation to Senator Crane and the fact that he has produced for us this afternoon such a pathetic matter for an urgency motion. Such an otherwise moderate and charming person seems to have somewhat of an obsession with industrial relations and, particularly, our Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook). I do not want to sound offensive, but I do say that if Senator Crane were somebody close to me I would be suggesting that he seek treatment. We have an excellent Minister with enormous commitment to fairness and equity. This is not surprising as a result of his own industrial experience over very many years.

PARA.TAB: Those of us who have dealt with good and bad employers and have a considerable amount of experience in the field know that legislation of the nature that is being proposed is absolutely necessary. There are many examples of workers who are not employees in the strict legal sense but who are in an extremely vulnerable position with minimal bargaining power. We should not have to explain to those opposite who those workers are and in which industries they work, but they do tend to be people without formal skills and with very little bargaining power: the young, women who have returned to the work force perhaps or those who are in industries that are under stress at the moment. Those opposite must, if they are to be fair, admit that there are many cases where unscrupulous employers have sought to avoid award decisions. Those of us who worked in the industrial system dealt with them every day of our lives.

Such employers try to avoid other provisions, as Senator Bell has so graphically described. I have some examples, too, of workers who are styled as independent contractors. We are concerned about the fact that, in many cases, people who are not genuinely entrepreneurs are vulnerable to whatever conditions an employer would like to impose upon them.

The Government's policies are aimed at ensuring that such workers are protected from unfair practices. That protection would come in through the award system, not via the Trade Practices Act or any other piece of legislation which, to the vast majority of workers, are totally arcane. Even to a person of the education, sophistication and skills of Senator Bell, I would suggest that the last protection he would have thought of achieving would be through Acts which are not directly in the minds of the majority of people associated with industrial issues.

The Opposition wants to remove the protection of the award system by setting up an opting-in arrangement where the employer can veto the worker's desire to be covered by an award system. Of course, the Opposition raises, as one would expect, the bogie of this legislation compulsorily requiring all workers to become unionised. That is absolutely not so. If those opposite read the material with which they have been provided, they will find that allowing independent contractors to join a federally registered union is not novel. Some independent contractors may do so now. In addition, a union will not be able to seek among independent contractors a wider class of members than it may seek amongst employees under existing law.

The protection available to independent contractors under the Act will continue to apply and is to be extended to make it clear that an independent contractor may not be compelled to join a union, nor discriminated against on account of membership or non-membership of a union. Genuinely independent contractors will not be made into employees and will not be subjected to the award system generally. The unfair contracts review procedure is a more limited procedure than that which is now available under some State laws.

This is just an example of the abysmal ignorance of the people on the other side of this chamber and their approach to industrial relations as if somehow or other it were not real law: to get real law, one, for some strange reason, seems to be required to go to Federal courts. Industrial law has every bit as much legitimacy as any other law in this country.

I remind the Opposition, too, that such a procedure, the one we are discussing, has existed in New South Wales for many years and has recently, amazingly perhaps, been carried over by the Greiner Government into its New South Wales Industrial Relations Act 1991—maybe one of the only really useful pieces of that Act in a sense of fairness and equity.

The procedure proposed will operate only in respect of a limited class of unfair contracts. That brings me back to a point which needs to be made again and again. We are not targeting genuine contractors, genuine entrepreneurs. We are targeting those cases where vulnerable workers are in a position where they simply cannot achieve, under existing law in some parts of Australia at particular times and under particular circumstances, the protection that will give them proper wages.

The claim that housing costs will necessarily rise because of the Government's proposal is rejected. Senator Crane should just think about that. That would be true only if currently there was massive exploitation in the housing industry; that is, if subcontractors in this area are currently subsidising to a large extent builders or house owners. If that is what Senator Crane is saying, there will be a change. If, as we believe, and as Senator Burns has already said, the large majority of subcontracting within the housing industry is genuine—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will give you an independent assessment when I sum up.

—Yes, we have seen all those assessments. But I submit that they are based on the sort of ignorance that has been driving the coalition's approach to this whole question. It is also wrong to assume that any basis will exist for intervention in the housing area by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. All of the evidence suggests that there would be few non-genuine, exploitative contract arrangements. But, for the people who were vulnerable to those few exploitative contract arrangements, legislation of this sort is absolutely essential.

PARA.TAB: I give just a few examples of how this exploitation works. For every individual, it is a disaster, even if there are not hundreds of thousands of them. But in some industries very large numbers of people are vulnerable to the—we do not seem to want to use the word `sham' this afternoon; `spurious' might be a useful word—spurious arrangements under which they are forced to work.

The first case concerns the clothing industry and involves the creation of a limited partnership between 22 former employees and a particular trust company. The agreement appeared to be a sham—sorry, spurious—with the evidence casting a real doubt about whether the relationship of master and servant had been destroyed. The agreement, which was not registered under State law, provided that management decisions relating to the control of persons manufacturing garments were not exercised by the so-called ex-employees, the workers.

Each of the ex-employees was paid a weekly amount equivalent to the wage mentioned in the award, which was said to be drawings on anticipated profits—a spurious approach. The provisions for expulsion from the partnership were similar to the right to terminate employment. So in every respect these people were working under conditions similar to those that would be in their awards, but they were forced into accepting all the other disadvantages that come with not being designated as employees. The decision in this case was that all partners and associate corporate entities were ordered to carry out all terms and conditions of the award—unlike the situation that poor Senator Bell was subjected to, with a lack of sick leave, annual leave and all the rest of it.

Another example from the clothing industry involves a worker who was sewing women's summer nightdresses. She was paid 50c per nightdress. Quite obviously, she was an outworker. This is just one example out of probably hundreds of thousands of workers. She said, `Because the items were quite complex and the prices low I had to work reasonably hard to make up reasonable wages'. At 50c a nightdress, one can just imagine. She was required to have a business name. In the Industrial Commission she was awarded underpayments of $12,852.

Another example, this time from the cleaning industry, involves a Miscellaneous Workers Union case. A husband and wife were employed as cleaners of four food stores. They were told by their employer that if they did not buy a franchise right to clean the four stores for $19,170 they would lose their job. They bought the franchise and were paid a monthly fee of $3,360.50. In other words, they worked for nearly six months without being paid. Their work was subject to continuous detailed supervision by the man who sold them the franchise agreement. On that count alone they certainly were not genuine entrepreneurs. The allegation was that the contract was harsh, unfair, unconscionable and against the public interest.

In settlement of the matter registered with the court, the husband and wife received underpayments based on the appropriate award rate for cleaners of $34,000 for one year's work. One might say, `That is excellent. The system is working'. I wonder whether Senator Crane, who is just leaving, knows how many more people there are out there who do not know about the Trade Practices Act and who are simply terrified of not being employed at all and who, at this stage, simply do not have the protection to which they are entitled.

Another example comes from the club industry in New South Wales. In this case the club had originally argued that the applicant who drove the bus for the club's free transport service was an independent contractor. The club conceded on appeal that the driver was an employee. He had been paid at $5 an hour initially and later at $6 an hour, which was about half the award rate. The employer was ordered to pay the applicant the sum of $19,796.34.

I could go on and on with examples of this nature. But I emphasise that these are the very few that surface within the current industrial arbitration system where the system is able to provide relief for the individual who has been exploited. Sometimes these individuals have been exploited for quite long periods, at considerable expense to themselves, and in many cases they feel that to make any complaint at all would be to lose employment.

Here is an example from the building industry just to show that it is not absolutely squeaky clean. I emphasise again that it is not only the building industry, and probably not principally the building industry, that is targeted by this proposal. An excavation company was a subcontractor on seven sites around Sydney using a pool of workers on an on-call basis. Workers were subjected to exploitation including a very low wage rate, no workers' compensation, no superannuation, no redundancy coverage and no issue of tax receipts. The company often employed workers with no previous on-site experience, thus increasing occupational health and safety risks. We would say that it was a complete disaster in industrial and occupational safety terms. The Building Workers Industrial Union was asked to intervene on behalf of the workers. A total of $70,000 was recovered on behalf of members of the BWIU.

Another case study involved contractors who avoided meeting their award obligations by paying their workers on an `all-in' basis, thereby avoiding payment of travel money and overtime, and redundancy provisions and workers' compensation. It is exactly the sort of thing that is happening in New Zealand now, and it is exactly the sort of thing that the coalition would like to see in Australia under its industrial relations policy.

The Opposition is not interested in finding ways of resolving disputes through industrial tribunals and protecting workers who are least able to organise and protect themselves. It is not interested in equity; it is interested only in slamming a quite good industrial relations system, albeit one which could do with improvement. But this is the whole reason for having it. The Opposition has no difficulty with arrangements that undermine awards or permit exploitative arrangements.

In essence, that is the Opposition's underlying position. It is an extraordinary belief that without any statutory protection or legislative award standards—in fact, without any regulation whatsoever—workers, whether contractors or employees, will prosper and never be exploited. We know that is not the case. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion before the Senate that has been moved by my colleague Senator Crane. Senator Crane has so well summarised this issue that we are debating. —We do. After some nine long years of hard labour—

So I say, as Senator Giles leaves the chamber, we know exactly what her Government's policies produce. We do not have to speculate about the future. Labor policies produce falling living standards and high and growing levels of unemployment. They are policies which have led to the devastation of industry around this country and have prevented major project after major project getting off the ground. As I say, we have now had some nine years of hard Labor under Paul Keating, and we know what Labor policies produce.

I found Senator Bell's remarks particularly interesting. Senator Bell comes from a party which was essentially established to assist small business. The historical origins of the Australian Democrats draw very heavily on small business and the small business orientation created by their founder, former Senator Don Chipp, and they were continually endorsed until recent times by previous leaders of the Australian Democrats and previous spokespersons for the industrial relations area.

One of the major thrusts of the policies of the Australian Democrats up to about 1987—in recent years it has become extremely equivocal—was to encourage workers in their rights to reach individual agreements with their employers. It is not surprising that the massive protest meeting held in the Collingwood Town Hall this week to protest against this Bill that Senator Cook is proposing—who do honourable senators think was chairing the meeting?—was chaired by former Senator Don Chipp. If he has tuned in today and reads very carefully the Democrats' amendment to attempt to restrict the particular ambit of this urgency motion, I think that he, like many people out there in the community, will be sorry that, when put to the test, the Australian Democrats of today have again supported big unions. Senator Kernot will be tested in the next week or so on this particular issue. We will see the way that Senator Kernot comes down on compulsory superannuation.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not frightened of you.

—Senator Kernot does not have to be frightened of me. It is not a matter of being frightened of me. It is a matter of being frightened whether 100,000 workers will be thrown out of a job by this Government's policy on compulsory superannuation. That is what she should be frightened of—that is what I am frightened of—and that is what Senator Bell should be frightened of. We should be thinking of those workers whose jobs will be destroyed by this Government's policies. I have to say, Senator Kernot—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Zakharov)—Senator Kemp, would you please address your remarks through the Chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —Each time the Australian Democrats have been tested as to whether they will go down the road of supporting Senator Cook, big Labor, big unions and Bill Kelty, in recent years they have preferred to travel down that road with those people following those policies which have done so much damage to Australian business, to the living standards of Australian workers, and to employment in this country.

PARA.TAB: We have to ask ourselves: why is it in this country that we have to have effectively the most centralised, regulated labour market in the Western world? What is so special about Australian people that we have to so tightly regulate all their working awards and conditions? Why is it not possible, as in so many other countries, for them to have the right to settle their own working arrangements with their employers?

It was very interesting that Senator Giles today raised the issue of New Zealand. If Senator Giles had turned to page 2 of the Australian, she would have noticed an article which was headed, `NZ deregulation brought dramatic improvements for Comalco', and, `Smelter rejoices in labour reform'. So what have some of the policies introduced in New Zealand done for the potential of New Zealand industry to grow, to create jobs and over the years to pay higher and higher wages to their workers? This article tells us that in relation to what has happened in New Zealand basic labour productivity in this Comalco smelter has improved spectacularly. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The number of man-hours required to produce 1 tonne of aluminium dropped 31 per cent and was still declining.
The managing director of that particular plant said:
Comalco did not expect dramatic improvements in Australia—
in contrast, I repeat, to New Zealand—
while reform was limited to enterprise agreements—
enterprise agreements of the nature as defined, of course, by the Labor Government. A focus on more fundamental New Zealand style reform was needed.

PARA.TAB: This is the troubling question: why is it in this country that we have to have an all-powerful trade union movement—one that, I think, in the eyes of many workers and those in the community, seems to be more interested in trying to run this country than in trying to protect the real interests and living standards of the ordinary Australian worker? This Bill is part of this particular thrust to try to entrench all powerful unionism in this country while other countries are moving away from these types of arrangements. That is precisely what it is doing.

We see this in so many areas: the Government's attack on the AIRC; the compulsory superannuation levy; the Government's Bill to force amalgamations of trade unions against the wishes of many workers; and the Government's current attack on independent contractors. What does this pattern mean? It means essentially that this Government is moving as fast and as hard as it can to try to entrench the power and privilege of the ACTU movement in this country. I believe that, after nine years of hard Labor, of falling living standards, of mounting unemployment, that particular approach to running this country has dramatically failed.

Why is it that this Government is so scared of independent contractors? Why is it that this Government suddenly feels forced to bring in this particular Bill to attack practices which have long existed in this country? That is an interesting question. When the Troubleshooters case first emerged in the courts—remember that Troubleshooters have been around for quite a long period of time; this touches on what Senator Giles was saying as to whether independent contractors, as Senator Giles would have us believe, cut the living standards and the conditions of Australian workers—this is what an independent arbitrator, Mr Justice Woodward, said in the judgment on that case. I think this is worth noting and recording in the Hansard. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am satisfied from the evidence—particularly that of the men themselves—that workers who seek jobs through Troubleshooters, do so because it suits them to work in this way, rather than to obtain continuing employment with a builder. They are in no sense being exploited by Troubleshooters, nor do they represent a source of cheap labour for employers.

We have had allegations from Labor Party senators—I hope that Senator Cooney will not follow this line—that the independent contractor approach, the approach of free men and women to contract with their employers, automatically leads to a cut in wages, salaries and award conditions. On all the evidence, it does not. I am delighted that Senator Cook has at last come into the chamber. In many cases those who are working on the basis of an independent contract find that they are able to enjoy higher wages and salaries compared with those who are working under award conditions.

PARA.TAB: I suggest that this is the real background to Senator Cook's proposal. The background is that the independent contractors are showing that this country, the free men and women in it, can well survive without the Bill Keltys of this world and the ACTU constantly poking their noses into their arrangements. That is why Bill Kelty and the ACTU are worried about this. It poses a major threat to trade unionism in this country, particularly unionism of the nature that has been developed in the last 10 years under Bill Kelty, the ACTU and this Labor Government.

As far as I can see, the proposed Bill will cause widespread concern in the community. Senator Cook has already lit a torch; he has torched the prairie. I can assure Senator Cook that if he wants to pick a fight with small business in this country, he has chosen the wrong ground. The men and women of this country will not stand for the proposal which Senator Cook has brought before this chamber. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a debate about issues that arose as a result of the case of the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia and Others v. Odco Pty Ltd.
—It is about freedoms.

—Yes, it is about freedoms. That case is more popularly known as the `Troubleshooters case'. That case has been quoted at some length as an example of how people can negotiate; of how people who are on contract can come to a proper agreement which is beneficial to the labour hire company and the worker involved. The judge at first instance, Mr Justice Woodward, has been quoted and properly put forward as an eminent judge—and rightly so. In that context I wish to answer what Senator Parer said. He said that we are on about—
—Freedoms.

—Yes, freedoms so that people can negotiate between themselves. The case went to appeal and was considered by an eminent bench consisting of Justices Wilcox, Burchett and Ryan. The full bench gave its decision on 21 March, 1991 and said:

SPEECH.PARA: His Honour—
that is, Justice Woodward—

also found that the rates of pay offered to its workers were adjusted unilaterally each year by Troubleshooters without consultation with the workers who were nevertheless advised of each adjustment shortly before or immediately after it occurred.
That is the sort of thing that Senator Parer has said he is about; it is what Senator Parer, by way of interjection, has indicated he wants.

PARA.TAB: I suppose we come down to a difference of philosophy in this argument. It seems to me extraordinary that it is said—I am sure that Senator Cook would not agree with this; but it seems that the Opposition does—that where one side to an arrangement unilaterally adjusts the wages, that is consistent with the sorts of propositions that are being advanced that there should be exchanges on footings of equality between two parties, both of whom want that agreement.

How can Senator Parer possibly say that they have sat down and agreed upon wages when one party simply fixes the wage and says, `Take it or leave it'? That is the proposition Senator Parer is putting forward. Senator Parer has supported the proposition in the Troubleshooters case, as has Senator Crane. They are very eminent senators on the other side who no doubt represent the position of the coalition on this matter. What is meant in the coalition's policy by agreement between workers and employers is where one side states what it will get and the other side takes it. That proposition appears from the very case that has led to the debate on this issue. The judges continue:

SPEECH.PARA: He—
that is, Justice Woodward—

noted as well that the written contract between the Troubleshooters and its workers set out above did not include the whole of the terms of engagement because it contained no reference to the wet weather allowance, the six hours minimum pay or overtime provisions.

It is quite clear from that, certainly as far as the written agreements were concerned, that there was no attempt to set out in writing what was happening so that the worker could ascertain what was happening. Another part of the judgment, which has been put forward as gospel in this area, states:

However, the agreement that Troubleshooters are not to receive annual leave or sick leave or any payment referable to those entitlements and that no deduction of income tax is to be made from their remuneration signifies a mutual intention that they are not to be regarded as employees.
That was one of the tests that the court took in deciding whether they were employees in that instance.

PARA.TAB: The interesting thing is that this agreement has been put as the way forward. Under the agreement wages are fixed by one side, no annual leave or sick leave are provided for, the employee has to deduct his tax from the remuneration—he has to do all that work himself, and no payments are made for time taken off because the employee is sick or on holiday.

When you look at that case, it takes on a different aspect to that which has been thrown on to it so far by those opposite. The other thing that ought to be said about that case is that it turned upon whether the people involved were either employees or subcontractors. The High Court would not have a full hearing on it because it said there were not points that required a decision on that issue. As Senator Crane would know, because he follows this closely, those subcontractors were doing exactly the same work as those who were employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were getting more money.

—Does Senator Parer have evidence of that? Senator Parer, in typical fashion in these matters, makes allegations without any evidence and away we go. As I said, that is a case which turned upon two groups of people doing exactly the same work, being subject to the same orders and commands, and in one case, because of the legal arrangements they were subcontractors and in the other case they were employees.

PARA.TAB: All that this Bill that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) is proposing to bring in says is that if there are two groups of people, one of which contains subcontractors because of the legal arrangements made in respect of their work and the other one not, and they are doing the same work and being subject to the same rain and heat of the day when working, the independent contractors ought to be covered and given the same protection as the people who are doing exactly the same work next to them. If we are going to have an industrial relations system—and those opposite say that we should not have the system we have now—it is proper and correct that people doing the same work under the same conditions ought to be treated in the same way.

An interesting issue that arises in this debate is the difference in philosophy that comes through. Those opposite say that the individual can look after himself or herself and that we should get rid of all organisations. They say that it should be one against the other and that everybody can look after himself. That is a philosophy that is adopted on the other side. It is not one that we adopt on this side, and we welcome that.

Interesting people adopt our side. One is a body which represents a great traditional value in this society—that is, the Church. Let us look at what the present Pope, John Paul II, has said. I know that Senator Parer does not agree with His Holiness on this, and I can understand that. This is what the Pope says in an encyclical.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are going to a higher authority now than the High Court.
—I am going to a higher authority than the High Court. The Pope says:

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, society and the State must ensure wage levels adequate for the maintenance of the worker and his family, including a certain amount for savings.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not mention compulsory unionism.
—Senator Parer should just wait and listen. It continues:

SPEECH.PARA: This requires a continuous effort to improve workers' training and capability so that their work will be more skilled and productive, as well as careful controls and—
listen to this—
adequate legislative measures to block shameful forms of exploitation, especially to the disadvantage of the most vulnerable workers, of immigrants and of those on the margins of society.

I understand that those opposite do not agree with that. A reasonable proposition has been put. All I am saying is that we on this side of the chamber do agree with this. This is how the Pope finishes, and I ask the Senate to listen:
The role of trade unions in negotiating minimum salaries and working conditions is decisive in this.

TALK.START.PARA: —But he did not say it was compulsory to join.
—It is not compulsory to join under this legislation.
—Come on! In practice it is.

—Senator Parer is a man I much admire. Instead of making allegations without foundation, I invite him to look at the reality. If he looks at this proposed legislation, he will see that it is not compulsory.

PARA.TAB: Everybody is saying what a terrific idea contract labour is and that Troubleshooters is the right go. On 3 March 1992, the Herald-Sun said this:

SPEECH.PARA: The non-union labour hire firm instrumental in reopening the Camperdown abattoirs last year is now taking court action against its owners.
Troubleshooters Available is suing Famicorp in the Supreme Court, claiming it is owed $40,000 for supplying workers.

What happened at Camperdown is that the whole thing collapsed. The workers provided by Troubleshooters on that occasion did not receive the money from FamiCorp. I presume that Troubleshooters paid them.

PARA.TAB: Contract labour can lead to some terrible difficulties. People take on an improper attitude which leads, as Senator Crane would know, to some very bad problems, as has arisen at the Camperdown abattoirs. Unfortunately, in that case a person was employed through a firm of solicitors, Kroger and Kroger, on behalf of FamiCorp to provoke workers into a course of conduct that might have led to action similar to that at Mudginberri and Dollar Sweets.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was established in evidence.

—I will give the evidence because I am making a very serious allegation. It is only proper that I spend the last couple of minutes quoting not from an official transcript but from what I am assured is a transcript of what happened at that case. Mr Monti was cross-examining Mr Leeson who had been employed by or through Kroger and Kroger to go down to Camperdown. He was asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Well, what is your understanding of you being employed to observe?
That is badly put. What it should read is, `What is your understanding of why you were being employed?'. The answer was:
LEESON: Well, it is my understanding that these matters may be used in Court proceedings at a later stage.
MONTI: Against picketers and the A.M.I.E.U.?
LEESON: Yes.
MONTI: What sorts of proceedings?
LEESON: Well, along the lines of Mudginberri or Dollar Sweets.
Over the page it says this:
MONTI: For the third time, have you thrown eggs at cars of the picketers and at picketers?
LEESON: Yes. I have responded.

He agreed that he threw the eggs. That was in a context where he was trying to produce evidence to found a case similar to those of Mudginberri and Dollar Sweets, and he himself admitted that he was trying to provoke workers to do just that. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—In summing up this debate, I begin by thanking all speakers for their contributions and by making some observations about a number of those contributions.

PARA.TAB: I will begin with the last speaker, Senator Cooney. If he has done nothing else in his contribution—and he has done a lot more than that—he has confirmed what I said initially, which is that this proposed legislation in terms of the attack on our current contract system is really about the Troubleshooters case. Senator Cooney confirmed that quite clearly and highlighted a number of aspects with regard to that. For that I thank him. It is quite different from the position that has been put to us by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in the material that has been released, where he has consistently said that it is about sham contracts.

Regardless of what those opposite say about Troubleshooters, its activity has been confirmed as being legal in the true sense of the word through Justice Woodward and then through the full bench of the Federal Court. The appeal that went to the High Court was disallowed because there was not sufficient evidence or reason for it to continue. In its analysis of the case the High Court confirmed what Justice Woodward and the full bench of the Federal Court had said.

I want to deal with a number of aspects of the debate here today. The first relates to Senator Bell's amendment. It is rather sad that Senator Bell should put forward such an amendment because it is designed entirely to neuter or destroy the motion. In fact, I would question whether it really is an amendment. It borders very closely on being the opposite of the motion. Madam Acting Deputy President, perhaps you could rule on that at some future time, because I believe the amendment does not reflect the intent of the motion. As I understand it, amendments are not supposed to alter the meaning of a motion. This one certainly does.

I return to some of my original comments on what this matter is about. If this proposed legislation were designed to catch sham contractors without having any impact on anyone else and did not affect the full spectrum of contracting that is operating in Australia, which has stood the test of time, then one could consider it very seriously. But that is not the situation. Senator Cooney has drawn that out quite clearly. It is also drawn out in the proposed amendments released by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) concerning independent contractors. It has been drawn out not by me but by legal opinion, some of which I quoted in my opening comments.

I will reiterate some of the points I made earlier. The proposed changes are very broad in scope, much broader than Senator Cook has stated publicly. They are in no way limited to sham subcontractors or to agreements that are harsh or unfair. Certainly they would cover the housing industry. The letter I have from Gallens Crowley & Chamberlain states:

SPEECH.PARA: Disputes about Independent Contractors

Under the proposal, the definition of industrial dispute is to be amended to encompass disputes extending beyond the limits of any one state about the use or proposed use of independent contractors instead of employees to perform work.
Further it says:

Under this definition, the jurisdiction of the AIRC is virtually limitless with regard to independent contractors. There is no quarantine for any particular industry or any particular subject of dispute.
For example, a union might lodge a log of claims disputing an employer's use of independent contractors. This would constitute an industrial dispute.

The Minister knows full well, probably better than most in this place, how one goes about bringing on a dispute; he knows how it has been done in the past. Of course, under the proposals that have been publicly put out, it will be easy to bring on a dispute. Furthermore, that action in itself will virtually destroy the contracting system as we know it. Once again I emphasise that this is not my opinion, but that of Mr Terry Chamberlain of Gallens Crowley & Chamberlain.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can we see the original briefing note as to what they were asked to give an opinion on, so that we are sure they were asked to give an opinion on what is the fact and not what you imagine is the fact?
—I am not imagining anything. The original briefing was Senator Cook's own paper. One cannot get a higher authority than that. The letter from Terry Chamberlain further states:

SPEECH.PARA: Union Membership

An independent contractor is by definition an independent businessman and entitled to employ others in the conduct of his business. Properly, he should be represented by an employer association such as the HIA. The lodging of union membership for such a contractor is weak, although the motive is clear, ie, to extend union domain. However, in terms of representation, such a move would establish the sub-contractor as schizophrenic—represented by and yet a potential supplicant to and adversary of unions and union demands—
an impossible position.

PARA.TAB: We reach the crux of this matter when we question why we need changes to legislation. There needs to be a purpose if the legislation is to be changed. One of the tests should be that the situation is not already covered. It is worth looking at this section of the letter from Terry Chamberlain which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Lack of Need for Changes
If, as Senator Cook states, the sole reason for the changes is to catch sham arrangements or unjust contracts, then the proposals are wholly unnecessary for the following reasons:
(i)First, if the concern is to save contractors from themselves and to regulate unjust contracts, recourse can be had to the Trade Practices Act.
(ii) Secondly, if the concern is to catch sham arrangements designed to avoid award provisions, these arrangements are in fact already caught up by the existing Act.

The existing Act regulates the relationship between employers and employees. Whether the legal relationship of employer/employee exists is a question of law determined by the Court in accordance with certain well established indicia such as the degree of control exercised by the employer over the person performing the work.

A person is therefore an employee or an independent contractor as a matter of fact regardless of how he is described. Any person who describes himself as an independent contractor but who is in fact an employee, is still governed by the current Act and there is no need for any amendment in order to catch these contracts.
That already exists in the current Act. One then has to look to the further agenda to see what this is really all about.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cooney put clearly to the Senate the position in regard to the Troubleshooters case. The other point that needs to be made is that the legislation is about extending union membership and union control. It is about picking up the flagging union membership which has quietly decreased over recent years. That also is a matter of fact. It is not a figment of my imagination or a matter of emotion, as one or two of the speakers have suggested.

I wish to sum up my remarks by saying that the contract system has served this country extremely well. It has been an integral part of the Australian scene for the past 200 years. It has been a very important part of the development of this nation. It has been a very important part of the housing and cottage industry. It is probably the most important part of the transport industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it will continue to be so.
—It will not be under the Minister's current proposals. Transport will be caught in the net, and he knows it. He knows it will be caught by the fact that a dispute can be brought on.
—Don't be alarmist; stick to the facts.

—I will raise a couple of other points while the Minister rambles on, which is not unusual for him. I turn to the oncosts that exist in the housing industry. There is no question that under the current proposals the mechanism is there which would, in effect, include on-site considerations in terms of the cottage industry.

PARA.TAB: We have been informed that the labour component in building a house amounts to 25 per cent or thereabouts. What has been forgotten in the debate is the oncosts in the housing industry, such as the transport costs involved in getting material on site. Then there are the contract arrangements which exist in many parts of our timber industry for processing the timber, and a whole host of other matters. They have to be added into the total impact of building a house or whatever it might be. It is not just a case of breaking down individual aspects of what is being done.

If this amendment is passed, it will be a sad day for this nation—sad for its productivity, growth, opportunity and freedom of choice in terms of what people wish to do with their time and how they earn their money. It will also be a sad day for businesses because it will reduce their profit and their ability to employ. And it will be a sad day for those people involved in the contracting industry, because the net result will be that they have less disposable income in their pockets. For that reason, I urge Senator Bell to think very carefully about his amendment and to withdraw it. I do not believe that it is a correct amendment because Australia will be worse off if we have the type of interference that is proposed in our current contract system.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Bell's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Question put:
That the motion, as amended, be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 32 of 1991-92, Project Audit, Department of Social Security—Review and Appeals, Adelaide Office of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal.

—In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 33 of 1991-92, Efficiency Audit, Australian Taxation Office, Administration of Fringe Benefits Tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: This report on the administration of fringe benefits tax by the Australian Taxation Office is yet another in a series of Auditor-General's reports concerning the Australian Taxation Office which have been presented to the Senate. Each one of them has been very critical of the way in which the Australian Taxation Office has been conducting its own affairs. Yesterday, when I spoke on the Auditor-General's report into consultants, I made the point that the Taxation Office seeks to apply the most stringent standards to individual taxpayers; yet, as we are starting to see with the successive tabling of these reports, the Australian Taxation Office has failed to keep its own house in order. I also said yesterday that these were most timely reports as the Joint Committee of Public Accounts is presently conducting an investigation into the Australian Taxation Office.

PARA.TAB: When one looks at this particular report, which is an efficiency audit—and very lengthy, with a lot of material in it—one sees that it is a report that will, I believe, be commented on again and again. As all honourable senators would realise, when reports are tabled in this fashion we only have an hour and a half's notice to look at them. It is regrettable with a detailed report such as this one that we could not have a more lengthy opportunity to go through its 61 recommendations.

One thing that concerns me is that the recommendations seem absolutely sensible in the way they are phrased, yet many of the responses from the Taxation Office appear to be in the nature of `We know better'. For example, recommendation No. 50 reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the ATO consider establishing two specialist FBT audit teams in each branch office in order to achieve a high standard of performance in the conduct of FBT audits and to provide the coverage necessary to ensure compliance under self assessment.
The response is:
This recommendation is not accepted.

As I flick through the report, I find other instances where the response is that the recommendation not be accepted. I find that rather a concern. There is no reason given in the response. It seems to be simply saying, `We know better'.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, there are recommendations, such as those concerning penalties and refunds, to which the response is more detailed. For example, recommendation No. 33 reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the ATO:
(a)re-examine its policy relating to the imposition of FBT penalties
(b)issue instructions to all branch offices to ensure that there is a consistent application of FBT penalties throughout the ATO, and

(c)give consideration to modifying the FBT system to provide, as a regular statistic, the accumulated values on a branch office basis of potential or recommended penalty prints generated by the system and the accumulated value of penalties actually imposed.
The response is:

. . . the ATO undertakes to re-issue the revised policy and the FBT penalty guidelines to all FBT processing sections and to reiterate the importance of consistency in the application of penalties throughout all branch offices. Consideration will also be given to modifying the FBT system to report potential penalties as compared to penalties actually imposed.

The Auditor-General again seems to be pointing out the need for a system within the Taxation Office whereby provision is made to ensure that penalties are administered in a fair and equal manner across the various branch offices. Indeed, in the Estimates hearings, when we were dealing with such things as prosecutions and the manner in which penalties are applied for other tax infringements, we found that there is no centralised database which would enable the Taxation Office to have an even standard so taxpayers would feel that they are getting fair treatment from it.

PARA.TAB: I do not think that anybody would be surprised to know that the Taxation Office is the least popular of all the government agencies and that it is making a real effort to soften its image by talking about its taxpayers as clients, being a friendlier organisation and generally trying to soften the edges. But at the end of the day the Taxation Office has the power to administer very harsh penalties, and what is worrying is that we are seeing more and more evidence that the manner in which taxpayers are treated is not necessarily equal.

Again, I would highlight the distinction between the way in which the Tax Office has treated parliamentarians from the different sides of politics. Mr Keating, the Labor Party man, the now Prime Minister but then Treasurer, failed to lodge his tax return. What happened? He simply got a nice note saying, `Please put it in', whereas other taxpayers, ordinary Australians without any connections, have been prosecuted and penalised. That is the only Labor Party example we have on the record.

On the other hand, we have the case of Mr Smiles who has an apportionment dispute with the Tax Office. He employed someone who had two functions: one was private and one was cost incurred for the production of assessable income. There is a dispute with the Tax Office as to the manner in which that is apportioned. The normal way that that is treated is by discussions and settlement and, if there is to be a prosecution, it is brought under the Tax Administration Act.

I have asked the Tax Office to find me any other example at all of a prosecution for apportionment that has been brought under the Crimes Act, which is the decision that has been taken with regard to Mr Smiles. To say it is extraordinary that the Tax Office has chosen to prosecute Mr Smiles under the Crimes Act is to make the understatement of the year. The reason appears to be quite political, in that if he is prosecuted under the Crimes Act, his seat in the Parliament is placed in jeopardy and that could give an advantage to the Labor Party. If he were prosecuted under the Tax Administration Act, as is the perfectly normal practice, there would be no such jeopardy at all; he would be treated like any other taxpayer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why was it done this way?
—My colleague Senator Macdonald is asking the key question: why was Mr Keating treated in such a lenient manner and why was Mr Smiles treated in such a harsh way?
—You are inviting an inference of impropriety by the Tax Office. Is that what you are alleging?

—In answer to the Minister, who has a habit of misleading this place, I have asked the Commissioner and his officers those precise questions. I have asked them to provide me with any evidence that shows in any way, shape or form that the way in which the Tax Office has acted is even-handed.I asked them to furnish me with any case at all where they have chosen to prosecute under the Crimes Act somebody who is engaged in an apportionment dispute.

PARA.TAB: I have also asked them to furnish me with particulars of the Perth matter that I raised. A taxpayer was found by a tax investigator to have defrauded the revenue by $500,000—in the vicinity of half a million dollars. I have asked why he was not prosecuted—why he was let off—despite 120 cases of fraud being found.

There is too much evidence of the system being unfair and not being properly administered. There was also evidence given that at no point does the Tax Office bring together in a central point the nature of the cases that are being prosecuted. I have asked for a copy of the guidelines which exist between the Australian Tax Office and the Director of Public Prosecutions as to when, where and why the Tax Office will refer a particular matter to the DPP to discuss prosecution.

It is most important that we know how things are gone through, in other words, the process. A fashionable argument that did the rounds for a while—it came out of the public sector—said that we should not be concerned with process, we should only be concerned with outcomes. I said on that occasion that I believed that that was an impossible situation and it must be rejected. The fact of the matter is, if the process is corrupt then so is the outcome.

We have to ensure, and with the help of the Auditor-General perhaps we can start to find some answers, that we find a way in which the Minister is responsible for the efficiency, inefficiency, corruption or otherwise that goes on in his or her department. Quite clearly, during the period that many of these and other reports that we have seen cover, the current Prime Minister—the unelected Prime Minister—was the Treasurer of the day. He must be held responsible for what happened in that Tax Office during the period that he was the Treasurer.I know we went through a series of something like five Treasurers in a quick period of time, nonetheless, under the Westminster system we must hold the Ministers accountable for what is occurring in their departments. Simply to say that they were uninformed or did not bother to inform themselves will not do, because under our system of government accountability of the executive arm of government to the Parliament is essential.

If the Minister cannot uphold those standards—and I say this very much to the Minister for Industrial Relations—then resign. If a Minister will not resign voluntarily, we must ask the Prime Minister of the day to cause that Minister to resign, and that includes for such things as misleading the Parliament.

There are many serious issues raised in this Auditor-General's report and I find them very timely. I am sure that they will be most useful in the Joint Committee of Public Accounts inquiry into the Australian Tax Office. So that at the end of the day, Australian taxpayers will have confidence that the Australian Tax Office is run in a fair and efficient way. That is not the evidence that we have to hand at the moment.

—by leave—The report of the Automotive Industry Authority on the state of the automotive industry in 1991 is one of a series of documents that we have tabled on an annual basis. They are published by the Automotive Industry Authority year by year under its charter of reporting on the developments that have occurred in the automotive industry in the previous 12 months under the so-called Button plan.

PARA.TAB: In the report tabled today there is both good news and bad news for the Australian automotive industry. Among the good news is the indication that exports of Australian produced motor vehicles and components have increased over the past 12 months. More importantly, exports now consist in the main of completely built-up motor vehicles, engines and a wider range of components to markets in the United States, Europe and Japan, whereas earlier, the exports consisted mainly of completely knocked down vehicle packs to New Zealand and engines to Europe. It is pleasing to see the way in which the automotive industry is meeting the challenge to increase its penetration of export markets with both a wider range and volume of products.

One of the pieces of bad news is that in 1991—and, indeed, since 1989—the prices of locally manufactured motor vehicles have, on average, risen faster than comparable imported vehicles. This still indicates that greater efficiencies are required in the production of motor vehicles in Australia so that their prices can become more competitive with those imported vehicles. The report says that the task for the industry in the years ahead is to avoid price increases above those of imported cars, while matching their specification levels, and that if the industry cannot achieve these objectives, it will continue to lose market share.

A challenge is laid down for the industry that it needs to become more cost competitive while further developing and maintaining the improvement which has been evident in the quality of cars produced in Australia. The quality of Australian produced motor vehicles is the next issue raised in this report. Again, this is an element of good news in the report, because the research undertaken by the Automotive Industry Authority indicates that the quality gap between locally manufactured cars and comparable imports has narrowed significantly. Credit should be given to the industry for achieving that over the past 12 months.

Among the bad news is evidence that indicates that labour productivity in the vehicle assembly sector of the industry remains about half that of United States producers and only one-third of that of Japanese producers—the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) is in the chamber listening to my remarks—and obviously that area needs continuing attention so that labour productivity is improved.

It is the responsibility not only of workers but also of management in the automotive industry to develop working systems within the industry which will allow a significant improvement in labour productivity. Among those requirements is not only the way in which managers manage their labour force within the industry but also the need for greatly increased investment in the industry to introduce high technology production of automotive components and vehicles within Australia.

In the Australian context, it will only be possible for the Australian industry to reach the required levels of productivity if we embark on the high technology road of motor vehicle production. Therefore, increased investment in that area is absolutely essential. What is advocated in this report is what is termed the lean approach to motor vehicle manufacturing and the goal of lean production. That is spelt out in some detail in this report.

With my time almost at an end, I conclude as I commenced by saying that there is both good news and bad news in this report. It offers some promise of continuing improvement in the industry in the years ahead.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to follow up on that. The answer of the Minister for Industry Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has amazed me. He said that we want to keep second-hand cars out of Australia—full stop. I thought that a certain amount of competition was the essence of trade in Australia. Some time ago we had an influx of cars and engines. Australian importers started to bring cars in wholesale and they sold very well. The motor traders realised this problem and I suppose advised the Government. We had the non-tariff barrier of the ADRs. Of course, if we put ADRs against imported Japanese cars, the Japanese cars would have a big advantage because they drive on the same side of the road as us, as opposed to German cars or Italian cars. The Government, with pressure from the motor trade and manufacturers, went with the ADR. The Government expected the importers to go away—and most of them did. The odd company did not go away but came back to meet the ADRs, and they are back again.

PARA.TAB: That is why the Government came in with the $12,000. Senator Button has explained that the Government had no particular rationale for the $12,000. He then amazed me by saying that that figure might be too conservative. Is the Minister going to keep out second-hand cars—full stop? After all, the price of second-hand cars in Australia compared with the rest of the Western world is ridiculously high. The Minister cited a figure from Mazda of, I think, $6,000 to $21,000. I presume he went right across the Mazda range or perhaps he was just talking about the Mazda 626.

The Government has said it will use the ADR to keep second-hand cars out, that it was worried about safety and that sort of thing, which the company went to a lot of bother to meet. Having done all this, the Government admits that the ADR was not enough. The Government is now admitting that it just wants to keep cars out instead of using the ADR.
