TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is not putting anybody in a privileged position. The Government is concerned only with large volumes of second-hand cars; small volumes of second-hand cars are allowed into this country. Japan operates an industry policy—at times it is called an environmental policy—which means that it is unprofitable or it costs a person to keep a car certainly after five years and probably after four. That creates an enormous pressure in the Japanese second-hand car market. Because the cars are right-hand drive, there are three places where that problem can be solved: New Zealand, Australia and the United Kingdom. That is to say, these cars can be bought cheaply in Japan, taken to any one of those countries and, depending upon the market, a significant profit can be made.

PARA.TAB: New Zealand let those cars in. The cars entered New Zealand in very large quantities. There was a reduction of 20,000 in sales of new cars in New Zealand. I think the population of New Zealand is about 2.5 million. It is a very small market, so that is a big reduction. If that were multiplied and followed in Australia, there would be a big reduction in the production of new cars. New Zealand is now conducting an inquiry into the matter. I think it is much better to deal with the problem before it develops too greatly, as I believe it will.

The United Kingdom has a way of dealing with it. It is much less profitable to sell in the United Kingdom because of transport costs and distance. We have inquired of the Ministry of Transport in the United Kingdom with respect to second-hand car imports. The Ministry approves a prototype vehicle of a particular model. The cost of that prototype approval is $111,000 and it takes a month to get approval. There is then a built-in time delay for testing the imported vehicles if they enter the country in any volume. One hundred vehicles are allowed to be tested a month. A maximum of 1,200 vehicles would be tested in the United Kingdom in a year.

Individual inspections of each motor car cost the importer $3,000 as an inspection fee and usually, but quite arbitrarily, entail the replacement of some parts, thereby further increasing the importer's costs. Senator Panizza might say that that is a non-tariff barrier; I suspect that it is.

In 1988 in this country, when we received widespread representations from Western Australia—Senator Panizza's State—about the importation of Japanese cars, it was decided that that problem would be fixed by alterations to the design rules. That worked for a little while, but it no longer works. Rather than go through these tortuous routes which other countries have followed, we felt that it was better to be quite up-front about it and say what we were doing and why. In so far as that may involve special treatment for the automotive industry, as Senator Panizza alleges, it is only true to this extent: the special treatment for the automotive industry was determined by the Industries Assistance Commission when this was not a problem. Now that it is a problem we think that, as a government, it is appropriate for us to abide by the `special treatment', if one wants to use that expression, which the Industries Assistance Commission recommended in respect of the automotive industry and which we accepted—and we are not having it undermined by that. If Senator Panizza wants to go out and say, `We are the only country in the world which imports second-hand cars from Japan in mass volumes'—if he would be proud of that boast—I want him to know that I would not. That is why this policy has been embarked upon.

I have heard Senator Panizza say in the Senate—not when I was here—that this matter should be dealt with under the dumping legislation. I have to tell him that this is not a case of dumping. Dumping occurs when a product is sold in this country at a lower price than in the domestic market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or they have subsidised wages.

—Yes, but that is a subsidy problem. This is exactly the reverse. It has all of what I would describe as the pejorative connotations of dumping, but it is technically not dumping. I should say one other thing on this. It is very difficult to determine the price at which these cars can be landed here—various estimates have been given—but one thing is fairly clear: there is a vested interest in understating the price for the purposes of Japanese export controls and of our tariff.
—That goes on anything.
—Yes, I know, but that is true in this case as well.

—I thank the Minister for that answer. I understand that we will have a chance to debate this in the not too distant future, so I will not continue for very long. I want to ask the Minister about the $12,000 impost. Since there is a tariff reduction program in place, how will he then deal with the fixed figure of $12,000? I thought he might have had an ad valorem situation rather than the fixed figure, because if there is a tariff reduction on new cars, there is a $12,000 fixed limit. In other words, the $12,000 will be a far bigger component in the relationship when the other comes down. Apart from that, we will debate this another time when the legislation comes forward.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very interesting question, but I want Senator Panizza to understand that it is purely academic. We wanted a GATT legal solution to this problem. We could have done all sorts of fancy things such as the British do. But we wanted a GATT legal solution, and this is it. Let me be absolutely clear. The purpose of the policy is to stop these imports. It does not matter whether we have an ad valorem tariff or whatever; the policy purpose is absolutely clear.

—I have one more question on that point. The Minister said that he wants to stop the importation of these cars, full stop. Is he still happy to see the importers paying that $12,000 on those cars coming into Australia? I do not know exactly the average age of cars in Australia at present, but I think it is over five years. So, if these cars are five years old, the average age of cars in Australia is being improved upon. It is the same in New Zealand. I believe that the average car age in New Zealand is about 12 or 13 years, unless it has come down. Considering the fact that bringing in these later model cars can help safety, is the Minister looking to stop them completely, even if the importers meet his demand of $12,000?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, the average age of cars in Australia is considerably more than the five years that Senator Panizza mentioned. The answer to the question is essentially yes. The Government's strategy in the longer term is to produce better and cheaper new cars in Australia; that is the best result one can obtain for anybody. That is the purpose of the automotive industry policy. If we start flooding the market with second-hand cars, one of the immediate effects on the second-hand car market is probably to lower the price of second-hand cars but certainly to lower the price of the trade-in values which people can obtain trading in old cars for new cars. That is one of the problems which would occur if this was allowed to happen in an uncontrolled way. That is why we are doing it.

PARA.TAB: I understand where Senator Panizza is coming from. He has been brought up in that National Farmers Federation ideological environment for so long.

TALK.START.PARA: —The WA Farmers Federation; it's different.

—I was going to say that it is probably worse, but I notice that Senator Crane is present so I could not say that. What I am trying to say to Senator Panizza is that it is important, whether he agrees with it or not. I have heard one of Senator Panizza's colleagues say, `I could never agree to that'. That comment results from merely not thinking the thing through properly in terms of industry policy. I am trying to be quite frank about it. We are not beating about the bush as other countries do, and I want Senator Panizza to understand that.

—I understand what Senator Button was saying then and I understand the reasons for doing what he is doing. But does what he is doing amount to an embargo upon the importation of second-hand cars? If it does, why does the Government not just embargo them? I am asking that question purely by way of seeking information; I am certainly not making a point.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that. We looked at a number of possibilities, including an embargo. I do not like embargoes as an art form. Much to Senator O'Chee's concern, we finally got rid of—
—We need one.

—Until quite recently there was an embargo on wheat, and there used to be an embargo on sugar. We wanted to provide a solution to the problem which was consistent with GATT rules, and a tariff of this kind is. I am not sure that embargoes are. The policy decision was made, I think, last November and I went through all these things at the time. We certainly looked at several ways of dealing with it, including the United Kingdom route. We finally decided that this was the best solution in terms of a sort of frank, up-front policy position.

—I understand that, and I understand that the Minister is trying to recall things that happened some months ago. I think he was indicating that he does not like embargoes. That is fair enough. In the Minister's answer to Senator Panizza he said that he was trying to get them out, which is tantamount to an embargo. I wonder how the Minister rationalises that and how he rationalises the high and specific tariffs in the face of his Government's general policy of reduction of tariffs right across the board.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rationalised in terms of the tariff structure throughout Australia normally being applicable to newly produced goods. In the automotive sector, the tariff structure is applicable to newly produced goods. It was based on an IAC inquiry into the relative costs of production of newly produced goods around the world. We put in place a tariff regime for the protection—I do not hesitate to use that word—of the car industry so there was a moderate, steady phase-down of tariffs in that industry. That is now in place. The intention was to reduce tariffs to increase the pressure on the car industry to reduce prices and produce better quality cars.

PARA.TAB: The report of the Automotive Industry Authority on the state of the industry was tabled in the Senate today. I heard Senator Chapman talking about it and talking about the generally good result achieved from that process. That is what the policy is. One either undermines the policy or supports it. Having decided upon the policy, we decided, in respect of this issue, that we were not going to undermine it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, is the Minister aware of any reaction, and has he or our Embassy had any discussions with the Japanese Government about its attitude and reaction to this proposal? Secondly, in the town that I live in in the Burdekin, there is a very efficient, very forward-looking rice industry which operates without any government assistance. It is an industry which, of its own accord, is actively and very positively seeking markets in the Asia-Pacific region, specifically in Japan. As I understand it, there is a complete embargo by the Japanese Government on the importation of any foreign rice into Japan. I know that the Australian Government is supporting the rice industry by trying to get that embargo lifted so that Australian rice can go into Japan. I wonder whether what the Minister is doing in relation to the used cars might be used by the Japanese Government as an excuse for resisting change in its policies on embargo of our rice.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —There are certain rules which apply to international trade and there are certain rules of the game too. Firstly, without having specifically sought information, if the Japanese Government had an industry interest which it sought to protect, this is exactly what it would do, in my view. I have made a study of what the Japanese Government has done over many years and it is my view that that is what it would do. I think it would say that it is only the naive and silly of this earth who would accept a flood of Japanese second-hand cars into their marketplace.

PARA.TAB: The second point about the Japanese automotive industry is that it is well represented here in Australia and the one thing it does not want is floods of second-hand imports into Australia. That has been made quite clear, both in Japan and in Australia. I think the Japanese Government would be sensitive to anything the industry said about the matter. After all, the Japanese policy of making it very unprofitable to keep a car after four or five years is an industry policy in Japan, in part to support its industry, which is the best in the world. I think there is no possibility of MITI saying to us, `Well, because you are doing this with cars, our embargo on rice is justified'.

The debate on rice is a different matter. I have taken part in the debate with Ministers in Japan. It is an enormous cultural and political problem for them. I do not in any way defend the embargo. The common agricultural policy in France now is defended not so much on the basis of being a rational economic policy, but as a cultural policy. If one goes to France, people say, `We want to keep these villages as they have been traditionally. We want to keep these country towns as they have been traditionally'.

We have a problem with that in Australia. We do not have such a policy. No government in Australia has had such a policy. It may be regarded as a non-economic policy, but it is a social policy as articulated by the French. In Japan, it is also a social and cultural policy. Whether a little progress can be made in the Uruguay Round with Japan on the matter of rice, I do not know. The last time I was there, the radicals were talking about opening 3 per cent of the Japanese market to imports. They were way out—they were the radicals.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to advise the Minister that I was brought up within the WA Farmers Federation.
—A good organisation, too.

—We have an eminent former president here. If I were to follow its line, I would be looking for more tariffs rather than fewer. Having said that, has the Minister or his Government ever considered using the same system as is used in Japan of increasing the registration charges in Australia, which would help the car industry in Australia? The Minister has not yet told me what is the average car age in Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the last part of the question, there are official figures and non-official figures. Probably the average age of cars in Australia is about 13 years. If we take out fleets, it is probably 17 years. In my view, that is both an industry and an environmental problem. We have to do something about it. In the last year or so, the issue has been slowly factored in to public debate and government consideration. It is not easy to find a solution to it because we have a federal system and all the State governments are responsible for registration. As I divine Senator Panizza's comments, he thinks this is an issue which should be addressed and has to be addressed, if not this year then in the near future; and I agree with him.

—The Minister spoke about floods of second-hand cars coming into this country. Can the Minister tell us what the total percentage of second-hand cars coming into Australia in the past five years has been? Can he say what the projected figures would have been when he made that decision for, say, this financial year and next financial year?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot tell Senator Crane that exactly. I can find the figure, but I do not have in my head the figure for the importation of second-hand cars to Australia. It is very small. The people who bring second-hand cars into Australia at the present time are young people who want to buy second-hand Mustangs or something in the United States, people who want to buy various vintage cars and people who want to buy particular cars in small volumes. That happens and will continue to happen.

PARA.TAB: The projections vary widely, but there is every sign that this could have been a very profitable enterprise. I am not against profitable enterprises, I just want more of them. The New Zealand experience has been extraordinary. I forget the figure, but I think 90,000 cars came in the moment this policy was relaxed in New Zealand. When the inquiry finishes I think New Zealand will probably do something about it. But I did not want it to get to that stage here. Once we get to that stage, we have a huge problem on our hands. That is why we acted when we did.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make a general comment about the policy. I am concerned about the magnitude of the solution. I believe that the solution will have enormous ramifications on our trade with Japan. For example, from 1 May or thereabouts there was a 10 per cent decrease in Japanese tariffs on our beef exports to Japan. This solution is sending the wrong signals on the general direction of our tariff policy, whether it be the Government policy or proposed policy.

PARA.TAB: From the information I have collected on the import of cars to Australia, not only do we have a 10-pound hammer cracking a peanut but we also have a huge jackhammer attacking that peanut. The figures I have show that, from 1986 to 1990, some 28,000 used cars were imported to Australia. I stand to be corrected, but I believe that 28,000 second-hand cars were imported to Australia in the last five years. The solution is aimed at one company in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's not aimed at one company.

—It is primarily aimed at one company, or a conglomerate of five companies. Their target imports for the coming year and the next financial year are 1,500 cars in each particular year to fill a niche in the market. However, the other side of the equation that needs explaining is that those cars range from 1985 to 1987 models up to a retail price of about $23,000 with the tariff. I am talking about the Mazda 626. The new price for the latest model of that car in Australia fully imported is $28,000. There seems to be an enormous hammer cracking a peanut. It is the Minister's peanut, not mine.

PARA.TAB: This movement raises the next question—the logic of putting a tariff on an imported second-hand car. Does the extension of that policy, bearing in mind the Minister's comments—I do not disagree that we want cheap manufactured cars in this country, at the same time keeping quality—mean that new motor cars that are imported will have a different tariff regime applied to them in the future? The tariff on motor cars coming into this country is about 35 per cent, and they attract sales tax at about 15 cent. This, in effect, means that the cars that were proposed to be imported will have an effective tariff on them of very close to 50 per cent.

In terms of the direction that tariffs are taking in this country, it is the wrong signal and it is the wrong direction in which to go. I would add that in regard to selecting them in the manner in which they have been selected, there are currently many products, particularly agricultural products, coming into Australia and being sold on the Australian market which have enormous subsidies in their production. The Minister would be well aware of this.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has enormous subsidies?

—There are processed agricultural products coming into this country, particularly from Europe, which have enormous subsidies applied to them. While this might be a little out of place in this debate—I will say it anyway—this highlights the inadequacies of our countervailing duties in the current situation to protect our particular industries. Countervailing action is the correct method of protection if the product is subsidised, which in many instances it is.

PARA.TAB: I find this matter absolutely extraordinary. It is the wrong direction for us to be taking. It will give the wrong signals to the community as far as Australia's trading relationships with Japan are concerned and potentially with any other country.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —That little speech represents the 1970s version of the Western Australian Farmers Federation show. We are in the 1990s now and things are a bit different.
—How do you work that out?

—I will tell Senator Short how I work it out. Senator Crane says that it may be damaging to our trading relations with Japan. I do not wish to be offensive, but I do not think that is so at all. The Japanese are much smarter than the Opposition in the Senate. They understand these trading relationships very well. As I said earlier, this is exactly the sort of thing they would do to look after an industry in Japan.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crane went on to say that this was aimed at one company. It is not aimed at one company; it is aimed at mass importation of second-hand cars from Japan. If one fires a shotgun in a particular direction and one company happens to be in the firing line and gets a few pellets, that is unfortunate. As Senator Panizza said, we have tried to consider that situation. It is not aimed at one company.

Senator Crane asks whether there will be an extension of this policy to new cars imported from Japan. There will be no extension of the policy to new cars imported from Japan. The Government has put a policy in place in respect of new cars imported from Japan or anywhere else. That policy will not change under this Government. It is a policy of gradual reduction of tariffs. The last version was put in place in 1991 and it will not change.

Senator Crane must have been an avid reader of Industries Assistance Commission reports in days gone by but he cannot have been too avid a reader of the Industry Commission's report on this industry, which was published on 31 December 1990. That report laid down suggestions on the basis of an inquiry by the Industry Commission for the policy which should be followed in respect of this industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did it deal with used cars?

—Of course not, Senator, because there was not a used car problem then. The United Kingdom has dealt with the used car problem in a particular way. I suspect that New Zealand will deal with it in a particular way. It may be a bit late for that country, but I suspect it will deal with it. There will be no change with respect to new cars.

PARA.TAB: Senator Crane then went on to talk about subsidised agricultural products out of Europe. The appropriate system for dealing with that is by way of countervailing duties. Or, alternatively, we may get agricultural products dumped in Australia; and the appropriate way to deal with that is through the dumping mechanism. But these things are not dumped. In respect of dumping of agricultural products—Senator Boswell normally pursues me about this but he is not here tonight—the Anti-Dumping Authority has made a number of decisions recently in relation to tomatoes and a few other vegetables, which I cannot remember at the moment, which have had dumping duties imposed on them.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister said earlier that the $12,000 tariff is not aimed at any particular company. I believe that. I think he said it is not aimed at any particular car, although it seems to be aimed at the Mazda 626. He might have seen an advertisement from Mazda Australia headed `Don't be taken for a ride', showing a 626 car. It says that recently some used car dealers in Western Australia have been advertising imported used Mazda cars and to beware, et cetera. We should beware, because the cars are not designed by the Mazda Corporation in Japan for use in Australia. I hardly believe that Mazda Japan would design a car solely for use in Australia. I make that point in passing.

PARA.TAB: The advertisement goes on to say that there is no guarantee that spare parts will be available for these cars. Outside of the fact that the 626 uses the same engine as is used in some in vans, it says that there is no guarantee that spare parts will be available. I would like to see how they would be available by imposing the $12,000 tariff.

I had an experience in the last couple of weeks. We needed a ball joint for a Mazda B-2200. Where did it have to come from? It came from the eastern States. Generally I have found that when I am in a hurry for a part, especially for a Caterpillar or something like that, and it is not available in WA, I can get it far quicker from Singapore than I can from the store in Brisbane. That steering ball joint had to come from the east. When the steering ball joints turned up, our mechanic went a bit further and found out that he needed a steering shaft. Where did that have to come from? It had to come from the eastern States.

I am saying that Mazda made a big play on these imported cars by saying that there may be no parts. But Mazda does not practise what it preaches. We needed a couple of steering ball joints and they had to come from the eastern States. A couple of days later I found out I needed a steering shaft, which had to come from the eastern States. Mazda tries to tell us that by keeping these cars out we will have cars for which we can get spare parts.

Does the Minister believe that importers of new cars in Australia—with the Minister's blessing—such as Mazda, Toyota, et cetera, or the manufacturers of cars in Australia, should have some obligation to make sure that spare parts are available, especially in each State? Western Australia is not just down the road. This advertisement seems to suggest that if we put on a tariff of $12,000 we will have an availability of spare parts.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have never been one of those people who has regarded Western Australia as not being `just down the road'. As far as I am concerned, it is just down the road, and I think it should be treated accordingly.

PARA.TAB: I am not responsible for advertisements placed in newspapers by Mazda or any other motor vehicle manufacturer or importer. My understanding is that in New Zealand—and I do not wish to get this wrong—Honda and Mazda have been unable to supply new parts for some of these cars. I think the problem here is that of the second-hand cars which are currently being imported some are diesel, for example, and some are not. The point I am trying to make is that it would be a costly exercise to provide new parts for some of the second-hand models which are now coming into Australia. There is a legal expression—caveat emptor—meaning buyer beware and I think people should `beware'. That is the marketplace test.

As far as Senator Panizza's own problem with a Mazda vehicle is concerned, it might be a case for him to look at buying a car made in Australia. I assure him that they are much better quality than they used to be—maybe all the Panizza family will be out in its Ford Falcon station wagon next year. Again, it is a question which is best left in the marketplace for people to determine. I cannot be responsible for Mazda's or any other company's advertisements

TALK.START.PARA: —There are three questions that I would like to put to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) about the figure of $12,000. Firstly, how did the Minister pick that particular figure and what is the logic behind it? Secondly, why did the Minister not have an inquiry to ascertain, for example, the impact of the number of cars coming in? My third question relates to my understanding that under the old Industries Assistance Commission legislation, before a tariff could be applied there had to be an inquiry. Has that provision been removed from the new Industries Assistance Commission legislation or have changes been made? What is the position with regard to the status of applying tariffs without an inquiry?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already answered the question about how we picked the $12,000 figure. I said that it is not an art form. The art form is the policy which is designed to stop the mass importation of second-hand Japanese cars into Australia. If that happened to us—and it is a distinct possibility—we would look like goats to the international community. We would be the one country in the world which is a recipient of a large volume of second-hand cars from another country. I do not want to see that happen.
—How did you get to the figure of $12,000?

—I have been through all that. I read out the reason behind that to Senator O'Chee and I suggest that Senator Crane consult the Hansard about it. I have also been asked about the logic of the tariff and whether there would need to be an inquiry.
—I asked why you did not hold an inquiry.

—I understand that. To be frank, it is not a huge issue. It has become something of an issue because of one company's representations from Western Australia. Anything one announces in this job related to industry, particularly motor cars, usually gets a fair bit of attention. I announced this policy on 3 December last year. The only letters I have had—apart from those from the Taiyo company, with which we have been discussing this matter—were from people asking, `Will I be able to import my Mustang from the United States second-hand?'.
—I thought Brian Burke was into that.
—I do not care who is into it. The point is that they were those sorts of questions. On the basis of my experience, this is not a policy which is of any concern to the Australian community.

PARA.TAB: I was asked about an inquiry. As I said earlier, I was determined to knock the thing on the head at the beginning—let there be no misunderstanding about that. New Zealand is now having an inquiry and it has more than 1,000 Japanese cars on its hands and a number of importers. I do not know how it will unscramble that egg at this stage. I would not want to be doing that.I was asked about imposing a tariff without reference to the Industries Assistance Commission. That is done in pursuit of the protection of industry recommendations on appropriate tariffs for the automotive industry in Australia. Of course, a government can do that at any time by legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to have one point clarified. The Minister made the point that the Government can impose a tariff at any time by legislation. Can the Minister tell me whether or not the Industries Assistance Commission Act requires that there be an inquiry before an additional tariff is imposed? Is that a fact or not?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is, but only up to a point. It is not a fact should the Government decide to legislate a particular tariff proposal. As far as the earlier question about an inquiry is concerned, an inquiry, of course, would have taken a long time—
—Why would it take a long time?

—It inevitably takes a long time. An inquiry of that kind has to be a public inquiry, does it not? We did not think this issue justified that. It is not a big issue in terms of tariff policy—not a big issue at all.

—Firstly, I apologise to the Minister because I have been in other places and he may already have dealt with my questions. I think the Minister will agree that the Taiyo company appears to have tried to do the right thing all the way along the line. It made inquiries as to what would be the terms under which it could import vehicles. It has now fulfilled all those terms and if this legislation passes through Parliament that company will have lost very substantially.

PARA.TAB: I wonder whether the Government has given any consideration to compensating this company for the losses it would have suffered as a result of being chopped off, in effect, after it apparently had endeavoured to comply with all the Government's requirements. I am not talking about future profits and losses. I am talking about the substantial financial losses that I am sure it would be able to establish as a result of complying with the standards imposed upon it. I ask whether the Government has given any consideration to where this might end up if the Bill is passed.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —We had discussions with Taiyo about that. We asked the company to produce an estimate of the expenditure incurred, it has given us the figure and we are endeavouring to accommodate it. From time to time there are changes in government policy—whether it be tax policy or tariff policy, to take two examples—and certain parties are aggrieved by those changes. When we made changes to the tariff regime in March of 1991 some companies might have been aggrieved by those changes. In this particular case—and as I recall, it was a Cabinet decision—we thought that we should discuss this matter with Taiyo and the costs it had incurred.

—Those changes are usually prospective, and frequently it has been indicated that there may be such changes in the wind. I recognise and acknowledge that as a result some people may be aggrieved by a reduction of tariff. But in this particular case there is a retrospective element in that they went a long way down the track before the Government made a decision that they would in effect be stopped. I appreciate that New Zealand has gone a long way further down the track so that at this stage the damage in terms of past expenses may not be as high as it might have been had the Government delayed making this decision. Does that come into the Minister's thoughts on the subject?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite often changes to government policy are made without any warning, particularly in the case of tariffs and in relation to tax, interest rates and a whole range of issues. That was taken into account in respect of Taiyo. I think it is correct to say that we approached Taiyo to ask the estimates of the costs it had incurred in this matter. That was certainly in the Cabinet decision that we do so.

—Has the Minister any views on the Australian used car market? With the recession, high interest rates and all the rest of it that this Government has brought down on this nation, the life of used motor vehicles in Australia has extended greatly. I am wondering whether the Minister has any views as to what is happening in the used motor vehicle market.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought that this company operating in Australia, bringing these vehicles into Australia in competition with the used motor vehicles, would have done something to correct that particular problem involving the price and the age of used motor vehicles. After all, as Taiyo points out in some of its correspondence, people in Australia who wish to purchase a new car are not going to purchase a motor vehicle which is at least four years old and which is the old model just because of the price. In effect, the company would have made very substantial inroads into the used car market rather than into the new car market.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an interesting view if one does not know anything about the car market.
—Oh, come on.
—I do not mean to be offensive, but let me make the point. These second-hand vehicles first of all compete directly with new cars manufactured in Australia.
—Why? They are four years old. You would be buying a 1988 Mazda.
—That does not matter.
—You don't understand the new car market.
—Probably not. The second point is that what Senator Lewis says is just not the experience in New Zealand—it is not the experience at all.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, what has been introduced into the used car market is a factor which would contribute to lowering the price of used cars. What that does is lower the price of trade-in values on new cars. One cannot separate the used car market from the new car market and say that these are the world's used car buyers—perhaps in John Hewson or Ian McLachlan's terms, the workers—and over there are the people who buy new cars. One cannot say they are two distinct groups because they are not. The two markets are very much related to each other. So I think those factors have to be taken into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to demonstrate Senator Button's lack of knowledge of the new car market, let me assure him that if he had been following the new car market over the last six or eight months, he would have seen the older models being sold at prices up to $10,000 less than the current new models, yet those new models have now come on the market. The sales of those new cars are taking place at prices that are up to $10,000 more than the price of a 1991 motor vehicle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most people in this chamber will be aware of the film, The Lighthorsemen. What is less well known to the general public is that the successor to the unit, which participated in the famous charge at Beersheba in World War I, is still in existence and is now headquartered in the City of Fitzroy in Victoria. Beersheba is located in what was then called Palestine, which formed part of the Turkish Empire. The town is south-east of Gaza and the battle was fought on 30 and 31 October 1917. This was probably the last major victorious cavalry charge in war.

PARA.TAB: Last Sunday this famous unit, the 4th/19th Prince of Wales's Light Horse, was granted the Freedom of the City of Fitzroy and, as they say, marched with swords drawn, bayonets fixed, bands playing, drums beating and flags flying. I understand that the tradition of granting freedom of the city dates from Roman times. Legions were allowed into the city of Rome only on special occasions—typically after a great victory had been won. There were some 250 men and women on parade last Sunday. The senior army officers General Glenny and Brigadier McManus attended the parade and the salute was taken by the distinguished and popular Mayor of Fitzroy, Angela Ireland.

The regiment traces its roots back to the Crimean War in the 1850s, when it was raised as part of a volunteer movement, although the exact date is unknown. By 1863, the title `Prince of Wales's' was bestowed on the successor of the first unit to honour the marriage of the heir apparent. The origins of today's 4th/19th Prince of Wales's Light Horse stem from three separate organisations: the 17th Prince of Wales's Light Horse, the 19th Yarrowee Light Horse and the 4th ex-Corangamite Light Horse. The three regiments were amalgamated on 1 April 1948. Last Sunday also marked the linking of the 4th/19th Prince of Wales's Light Horse and the 8/13th Victorian Mounted Rifles.

The 4th Light Horse was the only Australian unit to see service in all three fronts of World War I, namely, France, Gallipoli and Palestine. As a result of this service, it was presented with no less than 24 battle honours. Although the unit has primarily existed as a volunteer or Reservist unit, it did raise a Regular Army squadron in the early 1960s in order to send a troop to Vietnam to support Australian operations in that theatre in 1965-66. As a result of that tour of duty, the regiment earned the `US Meritorious Unit' commendation, becoming the only reserve unit in Australia to do so.

The role of the 4th/19th Prince of Wales's Light Horse today is quite different from the unit's role in the original light horse days. The once crucial role of horses made way for Grant and Centurion tanks, the Ferret Scout Cars and, today, M113A1 armoured reconnaissance vehicles. Another important change since the unit's early days is the appointment of women within the unit. Lieutenant Andrea Heath is the unit's transport officer and there are some 45 other women in the unit.

In peacetime, the unit has centred largely on the community, and has often been called upon in emergency situations. The bravery which has won the unit recognition during wartime in the past was prevalent again during the devastating Ash Wednesday bushfires which swept through Victoria and, more recently, the unit was involved in relief work during the Gippsland floods.

The current commanding officer of the 4th/19th Prince of Wales's Light Horse is Lieutenant Colonel Peter Fernleigh, who commands the regiment's headquarters in Fitzroy and its three squadrons located at Carlton, Albury and Gippsland. I was shown over the regimental museum by Captain Peter Bavington and Lieutenant Steven Blacker. The pride of the regimental museum is the Kyneton District Mounted Rifle Colours which had been made by the ladies of the Kyneton district for the unit in the 1870s. These colours are recognised by the Australian War Memorial as the oldest colours still in existence in the Australian defence forces.
The Mayor, Angela Ireland, gave a moving tribute to this regiment and the importance of the occasion. I will quote a brief extract from her speech. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: We believe by honouring this regiment we are honouring the real Australians, the every day Australians who contribute so much to their country and often go unrecognised.

PARA.TAB: We are paying tribute to these real Australians the anonymous people who have gone out and contributed so much in the past and the present for their country not for personal gain or glory but for the love of their country and for the love of their fellow country men and women.

By honouring these real Australians here today we are raising the level of consciousness, of civic pride, uplifting the national spirit of people, proud to be Australians whatever their origins may have been.

Collectively today, we are all Australians and very proud of it. Today in this historic ceremony we are showing an act of faith in our fellow Australian men and women. It shows a commitment by the City of Fitzroy to the everyday Australians of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The Mayor concluded:
By acknowledging our history we are taking a giant step forward, we are giving honour and paying tribute to our heritage, to our country and our flag.
I was interested to read that Lieutenant Colonel Fernleigh said:
We regard the Freedom of the City as a celebration of respect, trust and legitimacy of the regiments place in the community.

The regiment's motto `I serve' is as appropriate today as it was in 1863. It is appropriate also that the Senate honour this evening the commitment of the officers, men and women of the 4th/19th Prince of Wales's Light Horse. In conclusion, this October will mark the seventy-fifth anniversary of the charge at Beersheba. We wish the men and women of the 4th/19th Prince of Wales's Light Horse well on this important occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a matter of importance to all Australians. Australia's rivers and streams have become collectors and carriers of the residues of our polluting, throw-away style of life. The blue-green algae problem we can now expect to see in our waterways is perhaps the most visible manifestation of the consequences of that lifestyle. The problem is widespread with an increasing number of incidents being reported.

PARA.TAB: Only recently I have been given an account of one lady's investigation of a report of dead and dying fish in the Barwon River near Moree in northern New South Wales. I want to share this lady's account with the Senate, and I do so in her words. She states:

SPEECH.PARA: At approximately 2.20pm on the 7th January 1991, I received a call reporting many dead and dying fish in the Barwon River.

PARA.TAB: As the Barwon forms the Border between Qld and NSW and also because the town of Mungindi is on both sides of the Border, I rang the Qld police, Snr Constable Terry Hickey and said I thought there could be a breach of the Clean Waters Act and asked him to accompany me to the reported site.

I then rang the Qld Department of Environment and Heritage and spoke to Ernst Bruynius and Dr Richard Whyte of the NSW State Pollution Control Commission. Both asked me to investigate further and said they would stand by till they heard from me. Constable Hickey and I proceeded to the site, where at this period of time there were hundreds of dead and dying fish. From considerable previous experience with fish kills, the fish appeared to be dying from a chemical. We took the first fish sample at 3.01pm and wrapped it in foil. I also took the PH of the water which read 7.

Constable Hickey and myself then followed the river in an attempt to discover a source of a possible chemical entry. We discovered where a run-off from a Qld Cotton Farm had entered the river, and as we were on the NSW side of the river, Constable Hickey swam the river to investigate further. We could find no dead fish above this point. We took a water sample and a fish sample at this point at 4.09pm.
We investigated further up stream but there were no dead fish above this point.
We then returned below the entry point and took some more fish samples.
We returned home at approx 4.50pm. I put the foil wrapped fish samples in the freezer, then rang Ernst Bruynius and Dr Richard Whyte, with the findings.

Dr Richard Whyte rang back to say Water Resources and the Health Surveyor from Moree would pick me up at my home at approx 8.00pm, also that Tony Flynn, Dept of Fisheries and Robert O'Hern would be at my home 7.00am the next day.

At 8.00pm, Paul Keyte, and Peter Jones Moree Shire Plains Health Surveyor arrived and we again proceeded to the site of the fish kill. They took water and fish samples. We were somewhat hampered by the darkness. We went well above point of entry of run-off because it was too dark to get in closer. We found a couple of more dead fish, but these were in a much more decomposed state than those at the site or those of the afternoon.

At approximately 7.00am the next day Tony Flynn, Fisheries and Robert O'Hern from the State Pollution Control Commission arrived at my home, and we again proceeded to the site. We launched a boat and went to the point of entry, taking fish and water samples. By this time there were many more fish dead (about a couple of thousand). Tony Flynn took a sediment sample from the river edge where the water had entered also water samples.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not clear, but I am quoting the actual words so I will read it as it reads. She continues:

We proceeded up stream some distance and we ran into a really massive fish kill, 5,000 would be a conservative estimate, dead fish were littered right across the river from miles up stream, from tiny fish to very large Murray Cod. Some of the larger fish had cancers on them. My comment at the time was: `Could this be a warning, like the canary in the Mines'.

PARA.TAB: We eventually came to the end of this carnage at a NSW cotton farm. We travelled a few miles above this point twice but could find no evidence of any dead fish, but back at the cotton farm the fish were still dying. The only point of run-off entry was well below where the fish were dead and dying. It could have contributed to the kill but the main cause in this second kill had to be spray drift and/or overspray.

The owner of the cotton farm when interviewed admitted aerial spraying a couple of days before. He aerial sprayed his own crop and I believe he appeared in Court to get a rap on the knuckles for doing this, but that was all. Water and fish samples were taken from this fish kill also.
Ernst Bruynius arrived from Qld to investigate the first fish kill on the 9.1.91. I handed over the fish samples to him and he took water and sediment samples.
All samples from both kills, water, fish and sediment, examined by Qld and NSW authorities came up positive for Endosulfan.

Endosulfan was also found in the Mungindi water supply, which is drawn from the Barwon River. The rotten fish was also going into the water supply. Qld maintained they could do nothing because their legislation does not cover it.

SPEECH.PARA: What I have read to the Senate is an alarming account of one person's experience with the frustrating situation of finding something on her doorstep and attempting to get the authorities to do something about it.

PARA.TAB: I have nothing to add to this, other than to say that I intend to continue to present to the Senate what I believe could be described as case studies of individual Australian's accounts of their experiences with the dangers of chemicals in our environment and the resulting effects. This is a mounting problem and I have many further examples that I intend to present to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night I added to my previous comments with respect to the new air traffic control system in Australia, with particular reference to how the selection was managed. I shall have much more to say on that in due course, but tonight I want to confine my remarks to a few key points which I did not have time to expand on last night.

PARA.TAB: The final point I referred to last night was the responsibility of the directors of the Civil Aviation Authority. I pointed out that they were showing little evidence that they appreciated the legal position that they are in. I mentioned that they have responsibilities and obligations under law. The company law of Australia applies as much to them, as directors of a government business enterprise, as it does to someone operating as a director of a public company. I drew their attention to the charges currently being laid against the directors of Compass. I suggested that there was a similarity in the two situations. I pointed out that their liability could in fact be greater financially because if the contract price of around $200m blows out and the service is delayed and not up to the standard required, they could be held responsible for that.

Of course, the other element is the accident rate. What we have is a contract being awarded to a company with a proven history of losing aircraft on its detection systems for its air traffic control. That is not an academic point. There are failures in the software program of the preferred tenderer—Thomson-CSF. There is a history of a failure to detect and record the presence of aircraft on the installations it has made overseas. There is abundant evidence of it in our own country: aircraft have been lost in Melbourne airspace; aircraft are still being lost in Cairns airspace. I emphasise that this is not an academic point.

I wonder whether this doctrine of affordable safety is not part of the current doctrine of the Civil Aviation Authority. My mind goes back to the time when Sir Donald Anderson was the head of the Department of Civil Aviation. He was arguably one of the greatest directors of aviation in this country. His slogan was, `Safety is no accident'. He must be turning in his grave at the thought of affordable safety. The Civil Aviation Authority has never explained what `affordable safety' is. Does it mean the loss of one major aircraft a decade or a year? Does it look at its statistics and say, `We have a perfect safety record in Australia. People travelling on buses do not enjoy that. Other countries do not have the same safety record as we do; we must be wasting money on safety'? If we are to believe that sort of thing, which is the doctrine of the Civil Aviation Authority, perhaps it is possible to select a company such as Thomson, with a proven history of being unable to detect aircraft in airspace. But even if the Civil Aviation Authority does that, it has to consider its liability. I would hate to think of what would happen if two airliners collided because one or both of them did not appear on a radar screen of an air traffic control unit at a busy airfield.
Further to the points I am making in relation to this matter, I refer to a submission made by Hughes Radar to the Board of the Civil Aviation Authority on 15 April. The submission states:

There are three areas where Hughes has reason to believe that the CAA Board of Directors did not have complete or accurate information leading up to the TAAATS decision to select Thomson as the preferred contractor: (1) contractor risk, (2) the source selection process, and (3) Australian Industry participation.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing the submission deals with is the Hughes software risk. It states:

PARA.TAB: The Hughes software development capability has been assessed by the Software Engineering Institute of Carnegie-Mellon University. This is a widely recognized and highly regarded rating system that judges the calibre of companies' software tools, facilities, methodologies and state-of-the-art software development techniques. A copy of the Hughes rating is attached. The level 3 rating contained therein is the highest rating given to any contractor.

The Hughes TAAATS software solution is based on a rehost of the highly successful Korean Air Traffic System. The KATC includes Flight Data Processing and Radar Data Processing Function. The system has not lost a single minute of operational service since it became operational in 1986. It should be noted that the capabilities of the KATC match or exceed those of the majority of ATC systems in operation today, including those systems produced by Thomson.

A few important points flow from that. We know that the capital of South Korea, Seoul, is very close to the demilitarised zone. Those of us who have been to the demilitarised zone know that it is one of the most tense points in the world. The need for the South Koreans to have a fail-safe air traffic control system, which not only looks after civil traffic but doubles as a military airspace surveillance scheme, is absolutely vital. One of the characteristics of the Hughes software programs is that it can accommodate both functions.

This is also very important for Australia. We do not have the money to have two separate systems—a national airspace surveillance system for the RAAF or the Australian Defence Force and one for air traffic control. The characteristics of the two differ to the extent that in civil applications aircraft identify themselves by the use of transponders and communication with ground stations; whereas in military operations people try to operate covertly, they do not advertise their presence. Nevertheless, while the detection of the traffic is different, the handling of data has degrees of similarity. It is an advantage to Australia to have a contractor who provides a system which, with minimal or no extra cost, will accommodate both functions.
The submission continues:

The TAAATS software represents less than 3% of the total contract price. Eighty-eight per cent of the TAAATS functionality has previously been delivered in Jovial software language. Approximately 60% of the software functionality has been redone in Ada for other systems. All of the software will be completed in Ada nine months after contract go ahead, and 15 months before the TAAATS need dates. The conversion of ATC software has been underway for one and a half years. This is clearly an area of low risk; otherwise, Hughes would have scheduled more time and resources to accomplish this task. In fact, the CAA based their assessment of Hughes risk on those software tasks that amount to only approximately 1% of the contract price. We have demonstrated experience and recognized credibility to believe in our proposed schedule and cost estimates.

SPEECH.PARA: The submission goes on to refer to the colour raster display. That is one of the points of contention. A huge amount of information is required to be presented. The old technology, the cursive display system with a light pencil, has been replaced by a technique known as a colour raster display. Not only is that in full colour, but it allows a great deal more detail to be put on the screens in front of the controllers.

PARA.TAB: Very high technology is involved. I am advised that there is only one manufacturer of those screens—Sony in Japan. Not only is the acquisition of the screen crucial, but the development of the software program to generate the symbology is highly critical. We are not talking about something that someone does with a lead pencil on the back of a used envelope on a Saturday afternoon in between watching the racing results; this is something that involves tens of millions of dollars and years of work to generate a system that actually works.

The CAA, in its claim that Hughes was a higher risk, accepted the assertion from Thomson that it would be able to supply a colour raster display. Since the colour raster display is the interface between the human beings in the air traffic control situation and the data that they are operating with, it is quite important. Thomson claims that it will provide a colour raster screen—although it has never done so anywhere in the world previously. Thomson has only worked up prototype schemes, but no-one has bought them. I do not know what Thomson is providing to the Swiss air traffic control at present, but I understand that the Swiss Government—with the small Thomson contract it has—is very dissatisfied with the display screens that it has.
This submission from Hughes to the board in relation to raster screen work stations says:

SPEECH.PARA: The CAA has underestimated another area of high risk in the Thomson proposal. Namely, Thomson is introducing a colour raster scan workstation. All their deliveries to date have utilized either a monochromatic stroker workstation, which is dated technology, or a prototype raster scan workstation. High performance raster scan workstation development for ATC Systems requires significant investment both in hardware and software. Thomson is believed to be at least 2 years and millions of dollars behind Hughes in producing a production quality 20" raster scan workstation. Hughes began raster scan workstation development in the early 80s. Approximately $100M has been invested by Hughes and its customers in development of this technology. Hughes has over seven-hundred and fifty (750) 20" raster scan workstations on order, some of which have already been delivered. During the RADREP competition—
which was the competition to replace the radar control systems in Brisbane and Sydney—
which was primarily for workstations, Hughes was selected as the winner; Siemens-Plessey was second, and Thomson was a distant third.

Of particular concern should be the development of a specialized graphic engine, as commercially available graphic engines will not meet the demanding requirements of an ATC system. Secondly, there is a significant amount of unique software associated with the Man Machine Interface. Hughes has accomplished this software work for our workstations for the Icelandic and Taiwanese Air Defense Programs, as well as the Canadian ATC system. Thomson has significant workstation development remaining which must be considered a higher risk.

Thomson is saying, `If you want a colour raster screen, Australia, we will give it to you'. My mind goes back to the negotiations. I am glad that Senator Tate is here because he slept through many a speech of mine on the new tactical fighter in 1978 and 1979 when, once more, strangely enough, we were talking about radars and side lobe propagation and other things that confused Senator Tate no end.

PARA.TAB: It was interesting at the time of the new tactical fighter debate that the RAAF team—we are talking somewhere around 1979-80—was looking at a number of aircraft to replace the Mirage III that the RAAF had operated for some years. One of the aircraft on the short list at that time was the Mirage 2000, which was a new aeroplane designed by Dassault. They looked at this aeroplane in France and it had in it a very basic Thomson-CSF fire control radar. They said, `The RAAF specification is to be able to have a look-down capability in our radar amongst a lot of other capabilities in the air to air mode'. Thomson said, `If you want a look-down radar, we will give you a look-down radar', as if there was nothing to it.

The point at issue is that the ability to look down with a radar in an aeroplane and identify a moving target at low level—maybe 30,000 or 40,000 feet below—is highly complex. No-one could do it but the Americans—in fact, no-one could do it but Hughes. There are all these returns. It is difficult enough at sea with the wave formation sending a random pattern back. Over land there is much worse. It is extraordinarily difficult to pick up a low flying aircraft. It is highly sophisticated software which enables a signal processor to identify a low flying aeroplane in this circumstance.

Thomson had no way on earth of developing that technology in 1979 or 1980, but it was quite prepared to tell the RAAF team that it could do it within a certain cost and, relatively speaking, within a very short time. Nothing could have been further from the truth. In fact, until one American worker in this field sold out the technology to the Soviets, it was exclusively the property of the United States. The tragedy was that, quite apart from the fact that the fellow who sold it out was a traitor, he was also a fool. He sold this technology, which would be worth probably hundreds of millions of dollars in today's prices, for something like $30,000 or some absurd pittance. Once that happened, the technology moved around the world and other people developed it.

Unless it is felt that this is a small point, at the time of the Falklands war it will be remembered that the Royal Air Force and the Fleet Air Arm were shooting down a high proportion of the Argentinean aircraft that were flying in in daylight to attack the Falklands to support the Argentineans on the ground through that campaign. The Argentinean air force flew in C130s at night to resupply. It did that by doing a low level insertion. The British Sea Harriers were then equipped with Ferranti Blue Fox radars which had no effective look-down capability. The system was very limited over water and there was none at all over land, so they could not detect the C130s.

So the promise that Thomson can just simply come up with a colour raster display because it is required in the contract without spending a great deal of time and money has to be taken with some degree of suspicion. I have only touched on a couple of points about that tonight. It is nowhere near the end of the document that I was quoting from.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to hear more.
—Very well, I will continue out of consideration for Senator Tate.
—Well, perhaps not everything.

—Not everything, no. I am happy to accommodate the Minister. I want to expand on the fact that the CAA board found that Thomson had a low risk. The document states that Thomson is not delivering a proven system as the CAA contends. At least two areas should be of concern. The first concerns software. The document states:

PARA.TAB: The Thomson design for TAAATS requires rehosting of their Belgian air traffic control software written in Ada from Data General computers to Digital Equipment Corporation computers. Thomson has not delivered a single airspace management system of the size of TAAATS that uses DEC computers. Consequently, Thomson must rehost all its software on a computer that is new to its software and systems engineers. In contrast, Hughes has implemented a number of its systems, such as United Kingdom Air Defence System, Forward Area Air Defence Command and Control, a classified command and control system, and the Intelligent Interface Processor for Germany on the DEC computers proposed for TAAATS.

It is important to note that different operating systems are used in the DG and DEC computers. These operating systems provide differences in service as well as in performance and responsiveness to the flight data processing and radar data processing application software. Consequently, the application software may have to be revised to

SPEECH.PARA: obtain the same service from the operating systems and also to achieve the same performance responsiveness.

PARA.TAB: Tuning of applications and operating systems software to achieve required performance requires an intimate knowledge of how the operating systems work. Thomson's software engineers will have to develop a thorough understanding of the DEC operating systems environment before they can be considered proficient and therefore a lower risk than Hughes. Thomson's software engineers will also need to become proficient in using the DEC Ada compiler instead of the DG Ada compiler.

There are many other points of similar worth. I will probably revisit this document in future. For the benefit of Madam Acting Deputy President, who I know has another engagement, I will conclude my comments tonight by saying that, once more, this is not the end of the document and nor is it the end of my comments on the subject.

It is most unusual that a company of Hughes' standing should feel the need to make this submission directly to the board of the CAA. After all, it is one of the leading companies—arguably the leading company—in this field in the world. What is even more extraordinary is that the board of the Civil Aviation Authority should dismiss this submission as being of no consequence.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 30 March 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What has been the profit result of the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) in the past two financial years?
(2) What contribution to these results was made by the Australian Submarine Corporation (ASC)?
(3) What would have been the AIDC results without the ASC contribution?
(4) Was the Minister or his office aware that the AIDC required funds from the ASC in order to show a profit?
(5) Did the Minister or his office encourage movement of funds between the ASC and AIDC?
(6) Since the ASC has so far sold no product, on what basis did the ASC distribute funds to its shareholders and what was the source of these funds?
(7) How much funding has the Commonwealth Government provided or advanced to the ASC; by what arrangements and on what authority, were these funds made available to the ASC?
(8) What is the history of AIDC acquisition of ASC shares to date, please provide details on dates and amounts of any acquisitions.

(9) As a major shareholder of the ASC: (a) what is the level of the AIDC's involvement with the ASC; (b) does the AIDC have a representative on the ASC Board of Directors or in ASC management; and (c) does the AIDC have any involvement in decisions taken by the ASC over what dividends are to be paid to ASC shareholders?

PARA.TAB: (1) The profit result of the Australian Industry Development Corporation (AIDC) for the past two financial years has been reported in AIDC's Annual Reports for each respective year, which have been tabled in Parliament and distributed to all members of Parliament.
(2),(3),(4) The answer to questions 2,3, and 4 is as follows:
During the past two financial years the profits of AIDC were comprised fully of dividends paid by the Corporation's 81% owned subsidiary, the public listed company, AIDC Ltd.

The public listed company, AIDC Ltd, has an investment in the Australian Submarine Corporation (ASC). AIDC Ltd and its business is subject to the requirements of the Stock Exchange Rules and the Corporations Law and has the normal rights of confidentiality and obligations of disclosure of other listed companies. I am not in a position to provide any further detail about AIDC Ltd's investments.
(6) I am not in a position to answer any questions relating to the distribution of funds by ASC to its shareholders.
(7) I cannot answer that. I have not authorised any funds to be made available to ASC.
(8),(9) The answer to question 8 and 9 is as follows:

AIDC was a founding shareholder of ASC in 1985 together with Wormald International Limited, Kockums Pacific Ltd (a subsidiary of Kockums AB of Sweden) and CBI Constructors Pty Ltd (a subsidiary of Chicago Bridge International of the US). AIDC's shareholding in ASC was transferred to AIDC Ltd after that company was established in 1989. I am not able to comment on an investment of a public listed company which is subject to normal commercial confidentiality.
